DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, I present the report of the committee entitled Review of Auditor-General's audit report No. 20 1993-94—Efficiency Audit: Northern Land Council, together with the minutes of proceedings.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report I have just tabled is the committee's review of the Auditor-General's efficiency audit of the Northern Land Council. The audit was conducted at the request of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), following concerns raised about the financial administration of the Northern Land Council.

PARA.TAB: The audit report was tabled in December 1993 and referred by the House to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs committee. The audit report covered a wide range of issues affecting the council's financial administration and made 52 recommendations.

At the time the audit report was tabled, the Northern Land Council had agreed with 49 of the recommendations and had begun to implement many of them. A number of the recommendations agreed to received only qualified support from the Northern Land Council. The committee decided that in reviewing the audit report it would concentrate solely on the recommendations to which the Northern Land Council had not agreed and on a number to which the council had given only qualified agreement. In a general response to the audit, the Northern Land Council welcomed the efficiency audit report but stressed that the results of the audit revealed no evidence of serious illegal or improper action on its part.

The committee notes that the Northern Land Council has agreed with the vast majority of the recommendations; ATSIC has agreed with all of the recommendations affecting it; the relevant agencies have agreed to work together; and the Australian National Audit Office will conduct a follow-up audit in 12 months.

Recommendation 3 of the audit report was that the Northern Land Council incorporate the financial reporting of trust account moneys in a note to its financial statements since they are funds of the land council while held in trust. The accounts should also include a statement concerning compliance with section 35 of the act during the year. The Northern Land Council initially disagreed with this recommendation. The Northern Land Council claimed that as this information could be commercially or socially sensitive it published global financial statements.

The NLC advised the committee that its original disagreement was to the publication of the details of individual transactions of the royalty trust associations. The NLC has now agreed to publish the income and expenditure statements of the trust accounts. This has been given effect in the Northern Land Council's 1992-93 annual report. The audit office indicated that it believed recommendation 3 has now been implemented.

In recommendation 18 the audit office recommended that the Northern Land Council implement a time allocation mechanism to allow the project based expenditure control system to allocate salaries and administrative overhead costs to project tasks. The NLC disagreed with this recommendation, saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The Northern Land Council questions the practicability of this recommendation especially in small sections working on complex inter-related issues. Time allocation may be appropriate in relation to projects which are or could be externally funded. This issue is being reviewed.

The Northern Land Council said that its disagreement with this recommendation was on the basis of the unknown practicality and consequences of time allocation for staff time on all projects. It objected to implementing this recommendation without first establishing the benefits. ATSIC accepted the Northern Land Council's argument that the practicality of the proposal is questionable. The NLC advised that it will review the proposal and, if it appears beneficial, will implement it on a trial basis.

PARA.TAB: The NLC advised that its 1994-95 budget will allocate salaries and overheads to departmental areas to more accurately reflect the costs associated with each department. The Australian National Audit Office has indicated that it supports this move by the NLC.

The committee notes the changes being made by the NLC for the more accurate allocation of administrative costs and its willingness to evaluate and trial time allocation to project tasks. The committee is satisfied with the NLC's response on this issue.

In recommendation 24 the audit office recommended that ATSIC recommend to the minister that he apply section 34 of the Aboriginal Land Rights Act, where appropriate, to include any subsection 64(1) surpluses of administrative funds from the preceding year in the approved estimates of expenditure for the current year; in other words, to carry over funds.

Following the receipt of mining royalties by the Commonwealth or Northern Territory governments, mining royalty equivalents are paid from Commonwealth special appropriation to the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account—ABTA—which, in turn, makes payments to the land councils under section 63. These arrangements result in land councils receiving in excess of 70 per cent of their subsection 64(1) income payments in August and February each year. As the NLC's requirements for funds vary between $600,000 and $900,000 per month, this creates cash management problems. The decline in mining royalties and their equivalent payments to the ABTA has resulted in land councils requiring more supplementary subsection 64(7) funding to meet their administrative costs in pursuit of their statutory functions.

The audit office was concerned that the drain on ABTA reserves be minimised. It pointed out by way of contrast that the Central Land Council had offset administrative surpluses against next year's budget and decreased their draw on the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account.

The NLC disagreed with this recommendation querying which circumstances would be considered appropriate. The audit office believes that the appropriateness of an approach to a surplus is a matter for resolution between the minister and the land council. In a letter to the NLC following the release of the audit report the minister indicated his support for the recommendation. ATSIC has also supported the recommendation. The NLC said that it will make a submission to the minister on its interpretation of the legal position. The committee strongly believes that surpluses of administrative funds should be carried over to the following year, wherever possible, to avoid further drawing on Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account reserves.

In recommendation 5 the audit office recommended that the Northern Land Council cease the practice of providing advances to the chairman and council members and recover all outstanding amounts forthwith. The Northern Land Council gave only qualified agreement to this recommendation. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Northern Land Council is placing greater scrutiny on advances but reserves the right to provide advances under extenuating circumstances.

The Northern Land Council makes advances to council members of travelling and mileage allowances. Some other advances are made to council members for non-council related expenses when requested. These moneys are advanced on the grounds that the council members will become entitled to sitting fees at some time in the future and that moneys advanced to them can be recovered from these sitting fees. The relevant remuneration tribunal determination provides that the chairman must certify attendance before payment is made.

PARA.TAB: The audit office considers that the provision of cash advances and payment of the chairman's personal credit card accounts by the Northern Land Council—subject to later repayment by the chairman—and the making of advances to council members is inappropriate and in contravention of the full council resolution prohibiting advances to members. The committee believes that the audit report recommendation should be fully implemented. The committee understands that the full council of the Northern Land Council considered this matter at its meeting in mid-March. It deferred making a decision until its next full meeting but affirmed that, in the meantime, the decision of the full meeting of June 1987 to cease advances should stand.

In recommendation No. 6 the audit office recommended that the Northern Land Council seek the advice of the Department of Industrial Relations and the Department of Finance as to the appropriateness of its present flexible remuneration arrangements and develop guidelines for their continuing application. The Department of Industrial Relations advised that the benefits included in the Northern Land Council's flexible remuneration packages are not significantly different from those applied by other Commonwealth statutory authorities to their senior executives and other senior staff.

The audit report also points out that prior to implementing the flexible remuneration packages the Northern Land Council did not consult with, nor gain the approval of, the Department of Industrial Relations, as was required by the Aboriginal Land Rights Act at the time. In addition, the Northern Land Council did not consult with the Department of Finance regarding superannuation arrangements for those staff in receipt of the packages. The audit office points out that, as this has not been approved by the Minister for Finance, it may constitute an unapproved superannuation arrangement which, under section 7 of the Supervisory Mechanisms Act, is void in law. The Northern Land Council may also be acting in contravention of its superannuation trust deed if it does not allow increased contributions.

The Northern Land Council operates under a paid rates award—the Public Service Union (Central and Northern Land Councils) Award 1990—which specifies the salary range for staff. Flexible packaging may be negotiated with the union in the context of workplace bargaining. However, the audit report says the Northern Land Council gave only qualified support to this recommendation.

On the evidence provided, the committee believes that the Northern Land Council should be able to negotiate acceptance of these remuneration arrangements. While these negotiations may take some time, their effective resolution will be able to be assessed in the follow-up audit.

In recommendation 52, the audit office recommended that ATSIC encourage regional councils to consult extensively with land councils especially in relation to the development of their regional plans. The Northern Land Council gave only qualified support to this recommendation.

The committee recognises that both bodies have their own statutory objectives and responsibilities. The committee agrees with the audit office that a closer relationship and improved coordination would benefit the effectiveness of both organisations. The proposal by ATSIC for the development of a formal protocol which would detail the specific roles and responsibilities of the respective organisations is strongly endorsed by the committee.

The committee believes that there is now almost total agreement on the 52 recommendations of the audit report. The Northern Land Council has recognised the need to improve its administrative systems and management practices and has made considerable progress towards achieving these improvements. The Northern Land Council has indicated a strategic and corporate planning process and taken action to address some of the immediate organisational issues. The Northern Land Council's action plan for the implementation of the Auditor-General's recommendations indicates a strong commitment to improving the effectiveness of the council.

The committee believes that the implementation of these changes will result in a stronger, more effective council, to the greater benefit of its constituents. I thank the committee secretariat—in particular, Allan Kelly, Trish Carling and Penne Humphries—for its hard work on the preparation of this report, and I thank all other committee members for their involvement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted that this report has come before the House because there is a widespread perception throughout the Australian community that mismanagement of Aboriginal affairs and organisations takes place fairly frequently. This is why ATSIC has its own internal audit office, which is doing an excellent job.

PARA.TAB: It should be stated that this particular audit inquiry arose because Senator Grant Tambling raised it in Senate estimates committee hearings in November 1992 and May 1993. I think it is significant that the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, (Mr Tickner) said that `even before allegations were made in the Senate, I had independently sought advice from the Auditor-General on the need for an investigation into the financial administration of the Northern Land Council'. That investigation was warranted. Fifty-two areas were found where financial mismanagement was in place. Having said that, I make the point that both the Northern Land Council and ATSIC have bent over backwards to ensure that the shortcomings are remedied and that things are now going on the right and even keel.

This committee has a responsibility, not only to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community, but to this parliament and, indeed, to the whole of Australia. I wonder whether this particular case is merely the tip of the iceberg. It is in the best interests of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people that every opportunity is provided to investigate charges of mismanagement. I am aware of two cases in my own electorate—one which the Federal Police are investigating and another which the state police are investigating. I am flooded with complaints from Aboriginal people about mismanagement. This is not in the best interests of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island community or in the best interests of this parliament.

I welcome the audit office report. I certainly welcome the fact that both the Northern Land Council and ATSIC have really taken every possible step to make sure that these errors do not occur again. I believe that we should have the opportunity of having investigations, wherever those charges are made. It is not right that they should be swept under the table. It is in the best interests of Aboriginal people that guidance and help are provided in the financial management of their own affairs.
Motion (by Mr Gibson) proposed:
That the House take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with standing order 102B, the debate is adjourned and the resumption of debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Monday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)recognises the valuable and significant contribution made to world science by Australia's Antarctic expeditions; and
(2)celebrates this year, the 40th anniversary of the establishment of an Australian base at Mawson.

Mr Speaker, you can see that I did have a vested interest in sitting down at the appropriate time—I had to make way for the next speaker, who has a most important statement to make relevant to the interests of Australia in Antarctica. The Australian Antarctic presence is a very significant one and in the last week or 10 days we have had a very interesting concentration on Antarctica. Many of us would have seen the last of the six series on Antarctica by David Attenborough screened by the ABC last Thursday night, and the Andrew Denton program Money or the Gun on Ice screened last Wednesday night, which I must declare an interest in. It was an excellent program and my son was the director of it. I am very proud of him and Andrew Denton for the program they produced.

PARA.TAB: From last Monday, we had available for viewing here in Parliament House—on the House of Representatives side on the first floor—a superb and wonderful collection of Antarctic photography arranged by the Australian Antarctic Division. I congratulate it on the exhibition it has put together. It is superlative, it is first rate, and I would recommend every person in Australia, if they are going to be in Canberra, to make a point to see this exhibition which will been on show until the end of May.

We have this debate today which celebrates the 40th anniversary of the establishment of our base at Mawson. Tonight we have the annual dinner with the Australian Parliamentary Antarctic Alliance, a cross-party, totally bipartisan informal group of members and others who have been to Antarctica or who take a major interest in it and work for the benefit of Antarctica. As well, on Wednesday night we had the screening of another documentary in the Parliament House theatrette. So this does tend to focus the attention of Australia on Antarctica at the present time.

Throughout the 20th century Australia's expeditions to Antarctica have won international recognition for their contributions to the knowledge of the continent. Since 1936, when we took over the area that Britain had, we have exercised or claimed sovereignty on 42 per cent of Antarctica—Australian Antarctic territory. The expeditions of Mawson in 1911 and 1914 were quite dramatic. You might recall, Mr Speaker, that he and some others of his party were late getting back to the base, the ship had to sail without them and they had to winter and spend the whole year there waiting for the ship to come back.

I think it is of some significance that that great and wonderful Australian photographer, Frank Hurley, was with Mawson at that time. It is relevant, of course, to the exhibition which is on show in the House at the moment because the photographic coverage of Antarctica has gone on, in Australian terms, since Frank Hurley went south and wintered with Mawson. I know that Mawson and others found that eating the livers of dogs tended to make the soles of their feet fall off because of the excess of vitamin A, but I do not know whether Frank Hurley ever had that wonderful experience. I hope he did not.

Mr Speaker, I would recommend and hope that when you visit the exhibition you will take particular note of the photograph taken by Frank Hurley not when he was with Mawson but when he was with the Shackleton expedition. It is a photograph of Shackleton's ship, Endurance, which was thrust out of the sea by the pack ice and was later crushed and sank. This particular photograph was taken by Hurley at noon on midwinter's day, 1914. The ship is shown as pushed right up out of the ice—the sky, of course, is pitch black because at that stage there was 24-hours darkness—and he exposed the film by causing a series of 36 explosions around the scene at the same time. It is a wonderfully dramatic photograph, and I am particularly delighted that it was given to me by the two twin daughters of Frank Hurley, who live in my electorate at Coffs Harbour.

Australia's scientific association with Antarctica has gone on well beyond the Mawson expedition. In 1947-48 the first of the Australian National Antarctic Research Expeditions, ANARE, set up research stations on Heard Island, an Australian territory and our only active volcano, and Macquarie Island, which is actually part of Tasmania. In 1954 Mawson station was set up. It is the oldest continually operated of all Antarctic continental stations. In 1957 we established our base at Davis. In 1959 the Americans gave us their Wilkes base which we later transformed—10 years later, by the way, in 1969—into Casey. That was when the increase of snow and ice forced the abandonment of Wilkes. Casey, like the other Antarctic stations, has been rebuilt on a new site.

The Antarctic Division was established by the government in 1948 as a permanent agency to administer and provide logistic support for ANARE, the Department of Environment, Sport and Territories. The division enhances Australia's scientific, environmental, political, strategic and economic interests in Antarctic and subantarctic regions and preserves our sovereignty over the Australian Antarctic territory. The science program aims to improve our understanding of Antarctica and enhance our influence in the region by undertaking valuable research. This research covers the biological sciences, atmospheric and space physics, glaciology, medical research, science support, geoscience, meteorology and oceanography. In passing, I would like to pay tribute to the tremendous contribution made by the Assistant Director, Science, of the Antarctic Division, Dr Pat Quilty.

Australia is one of the pioneers of scientific research in Antarctica and we remain a very active participant in international research programs. Some examples of this are that our marine science program has added to the world knowledge of krill and the whole Antarctic ecosystem, and our plant studies have sought to determine what plants grow where and how variable they are. One of the fascinating things one finds when visiting Casey is the mosses, which grow quite close to the base. During the winter they are covered by several metres of ice, but with the thaw they come out; there is the moss, resplendent in its beautiful green, together with legless mites which live within it and survive the dreadful Antarctic winter.

We are also undertaking land based studies of vertebrate animals, the life forms of lakes and the study of fossils up to 4.2 million years old. Only in the last week we have had this wonderful discovery of a new dinosaur in Antarctica. This is part of the continuing research program which Australia and other countries are embarked on.

We have discovered fish with antifreeze proteins. I am sure that, because of that discovery, in the fullness of time significant advances will be made in research affecting the health of humans. We have discovered plants which make their own sunscreens. Again, this is something that will be of value to humanity. We drill the ice to get climate information over millions of years. The international drilling operation has revealed the evolution of the earth's crust, from a combined surface and underground observatory. We are very involved with upper atmospheric physics.

Mawson station was established in 1954. I pay tribute to those early expeditioners. What a wonderful job they did. I would also like to pay particular tribute to Dr Phillip Law, who was the initial director of the Antarctic Division. I believe Phil Law is a man whose contribution to Australia has never been fully recognised. He did a remarkable job. He established Mawson—named in honour of Sir Douglas Mawson—on 13 February 1954. Ever since, it has had a remarkable record of scientific operation.

In 1955 its scientific operations were among the most sophisticated in Antarctica and included the first cosmic ray observations south of the Antarctic Circle. From 1968 to 1974 the division launched the geological and glaciological research program in Prince Charles Mountains, 400 kilometres inland from Mawson. I must say that one of my most fascinating experiences was, unfortunately, not to have visited the Prince Charles Mountains but to have seen some of the coal that has been brought from there and also some of the fossils of leaves which very much look like gum leaves and which provide evidence that Australia and Antarctica were once joined. I pay great tribute to all Antarctic expeditioners and the contribution they made to world science.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to second this motion. I am also delighted to speak on this important debate, which is in recognition of the 40th anniversary of the establishment of the first Australian base on the Antarctic continent. This base was Mawson, which is now one of the three permanent bases that Australia has on Antarctica—Mawson, Casey and Davis—and, of course, there is one on sub-Antarctica at Macquarie Island. I know of no-one who has been to Antarctica and whose life has not been changed by that experience, who has not been awed by the experience. Antarctica fascinates because of the challenge of the unknown and of the danger, because of its awesome size and dramatic beauty, and because of the scientific interest in this unique environment.

PARA.TAB: It is important that Australia has played such an important role, as we claim 42 per cent of the Antarctic territory. In 1933 Britain transferred to Canberra sovereign rights of the territory—all of Antarctica south of 60 degrees south and between the longitudes of 160 degrees and 145 degrees east, except for a small part claimed by France in 1924. Australia formally accepted control in 1936.

Australia's associations with Antarctica go back to its known early European history: to James Cook's great southern voyage in 1772-75, the first to cross the Antarctic Circle. Many of the pioneering journeys of the 1800s in search of knowledge left Australian ports. In the 20th century Australia's scientific expeditions to Antarctica have won international recognition for their contributions to knowledge of the continent.

Antarctica is also of fundamental importance to Australia. There are three key elements in Australia's approach to Antarctica: its nearness, our sovereignty, and international cooperation, both diplomatic and scientific. For Australia, the most crucial point is that Antarctica is part of our region, our neighbourhood. It dominates the southern approaches in our weather. This nearness means that Antarctica is part of Australia's area of strategic significance. It also means that weather patterns of the Antarctic, the Antarctic cold transmitted by air and sea currents, have a direct effect on the Australian land mass. It affects our ecology and contributes to Australia having a great variety of weather conditions. Australia, incidentally, is the second driest continent after Antarctica.

This nearness also makes it natural, perhaps inevitable, that Australians should have been among the first and the most extensive explorers of Antarctica. Our records of exploration and scientific endeavour go back now over 90 years and are the basis of Australia's claims to sovereignty over a considerable area of Antarctica.

Nevertheless, Australia has been one of the pioneer supporters of peaceful international cooperation in the Antarctic—hence the title of the exhibition on the first floor of this building that I urge all honourable members and visitors to visit. It is entitled `Antarctica: land of peace and science'.

We were heavily involved in the international geophysical year in 1957-58. The level of international cooperation in Antarctica at that time involving many interested nations convinced us, as it did other nations, of the need to find a way of maintaining and developing that cooperation. We were among the founders of the Antarctic Treaty. More recently, Australia played a leading role in the conclusion of the Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources, the headquarters of which is located in Hobart.

I ask honourable members to imagine a view of untrammelled beauty, of stillness, a view of incredible beauty as far as the eye can see, a view encompassing the most incredible colours, a land of dramatic sunsets and sunrises. When we think of Antarctica we think of it as being all white, but it has the most incredible range of colours. All this, and more, is Antarctica.

In our ever increasing search for minerals, some people recently argued that Antarctica should be mined. Not satisfied with cutting down rainforests or desecrating some of the most beautiful and fragile parts of the world, the miners cast their covetous, greedy eyes on the last remaining wilderness—Antarctica. Imagine the scene described above with a great overburden of mining waste. Imagine the whiteness spoilt forever by huge oil slicks or the stillness of Antarctica pierced by the noise of mining activities. Recently the 39 nations of the Antarctic Treaty formally banned mining for 50 years in this the last wilderness continent.

Antarctica has been designated as a natural reserve devoted to peace and science. The Protocol on Environmental Protection to the Antarctic Treaty is a substantial advance by treaty nations in seeking comprehensive protection for the Antarctic as a great wilderness on earth. The protocol prohibits any activity relating to mineral resources other than scientific research. Australia recently ratified the Madrid protocol. Australia's concern for the environmental aspects of Antarctica is reflected in its current science program. It is interesting that in a world dominated by conflicts, of competing and conflicting ideologies and philosophies, long before there was international cooperation in other spheres, there was cooperation on Antarctica.

This is the last clean place of any size left on earth. How long it can stay that way I sometimes wonder because there will most likely be increasing numbers of tourists, ships, garbage and pollution in general. Already elements of pollution are there. I pay tribute to the Australian government for its clean-up measures at our bases in Antarctica. I believe that our record in Antarctica is second to none. When I was in Antarctica, as well as visiting the Australian bases I visited the Chinese and Soviet bases. Our protection for the environment was better than that practised at those bases. Recently, the Tasmanian government has agreed to the return of rubbish from Antarctica. I congratulate it for that. At the April meeting of the Antarctic Treaty nations Australia was successful in ensuring that the treaty nations adopt guidelines consistent with treaty protocols for tourism to Antarctica.

If the continent of Antarctica itself is largely a frozen wasteland, the waters around it are the richest reservoir of life on the planet. They support the familiar large animals of the far southern seas—penguins, gulls, seals, dolphins and whales. The sea is also rich in krill, which unfortunately has been overfished by the Japanese and others. If we damage the region badly, which, even with the best will in the world, mining and tourism would inevitably do, we would tear an enormous hole in the fabric of the planetary ecology and cause damage elsewhere.

Antarctica is without a doubt the world's greatest wilderness. This vast land and its surrounding seas are dominated by nature—by cold and wind, ice and snow. The continent itself is barren. Antarctic wildlife depends for its survival on food from the ocean. Humans can exist there only with outside support. In such a place many countries have decided to establish bases in which people can live and work. They have done this for many reasons but predominantly it is the desire for understanding. Antarctic research has brought new life to great questions about the earth, its geophysics, its geology, its ecosystems, its atmosphere and its place in the universe. It has also provided the world with an unprecedented opportunity for cooperation between people of many nations in the peaceful pursuit of knowledge. The Antarctic region is valuable to the people of Earth because of its ecological role and as a mine of information useful to science. This motion pays tribute to that.

In addition, we have a responsibility to try to protect and preserve the Antarctic in as pristine a state as possible. This is not too high a price to pay, and the scientific and environmental integrity of Antarctica is infinitely too valuable to lose through inactivity or in the name of dubious short-term economic enrichment. We on earth have mined, farmed and raped much of the world. We have done tremendous damage to this planet. Surely there is one place on earth that can be left in its pristine state for the benefit of everyone and for future generations.

I pay tribute to all who have been associated with Antarctica, from the early explorers who showed such great courage and determination as they travelled into the unknown to the early scientists and, over more recent years, those who continue to study in Antarctica. Here I would like to pay tribute to someone from my own electorate of Throsby, the late Bob Dovers. Bob and his father were the only father and son team to visit Antarctica. His father, George, wintered in Antarctica from 1911 to 1914, and Bob twice wintered there from 1947 to 1948 and again from 1951 to 1952. Last year the municipality of Shellharbour honoured him with an exhibition at the Pioneer Museum.

Australia's Antarctic and Southern Ocean program is pursuing some of the major scientific conservation and political questions facing Australia and the world in the 1990s. Australia has had a proud record in Antarctica. May it continue that way, and long may Antarctica remain a land of peace and science.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I pay tribute to the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) for introducing this motion into the House, and endorse not only his remarks but also those remarks made by the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis). As both honourable members have reflected, and as I am bold and almost on the edge of the standing orders in reflecting, I suspect the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) will be similarly making a bipartisan contribution to this debate because of the degree to which all of the Antarctic and Antarctic research has reflected bipartisan support.

PARA.TAB: I want to pick up what was said by the honourable members for Cowper and Throsby and recommend to all people in the gallery and anyone who may be listening to this debate that they visit the photographic display on the first floor of this building, arranged by the Australian Antarctic Division. I wandered through there and, Mr Deputy Speaker, you would understand my sentiment when I recalled the return of the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) from an expedition to Antarctic who brought back what are quite remarkable photographs of his experience in Antarctica.

There are those of us who, in our time in this place, have reflected less than charitably on what we saw as the relative insensitivity to some issues of the honourable member for Maranoa. We may well have been labelling him unfairly, looking at him in the light of his photography; or it may be that Antarctica wove on him the same spell it weaves on everyone else and revealed a side to him that others of us have not given him credit for.

Be that as it may, this morning I want particularly to focus on the second part of the motion that the honourable member for Cowper has brought into the House calling on us to celebrate this year, the 40th anniversary of the establishment of the Australian base at Mawson. Without any sense of parochialism, Mr Deputy Speaker, I stand here as a South Australian acutely aware of the contribution made to South Australia's academia and to Australia's Antarctic exploration by Sir Douglas Mawson. I, as you know, was won over to an affection for Antarctica after reading Lennard Bickel's book This Accursed Land, which was the story of Mawson's Antarctic expedition. I could not believe the courage, endurance, bravery and determination that Mawson had shown against quite impossible odds. How could one be so lonely, so cold and so ill for so long and still persevere?

I pick up just one of the comments made by the honourable member for Cowper. As I recall the story of Mawson's most remarkable return, it was in fact alone that he returned. It was alone that he observed that the ship had sailed and it was this emaciated skeleton of a man called Mawson who, having lost both of his companions, Mertz and Ninnis, struggled over the embankment towards the base and was not recognised by his companions. The one companion who rushed up to him opened Mawson's parka and said, `My God, who are you?' so emaciated was Mawson.

Time does not allow me to go on in detail, but I reflect on Mawson's courage as alone he had made this almost one-month journey, having lost both of his companions, only to return to find that the ship had sailed and to find a handful of his fellow explorers who had remained at the base lest any one of the three of them on the Mawson expedition should return, as Mawson did.

All of us who have visited Antarctica—I was in the presence of the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) and the honourable member for Cowper when we, with Mr Mountford, visited Antarctica—were caught up in its majesty, its grandeur and its isolation. In many ways, the awe that one feels at this remarkable land resembles some sort of spiritual experience. In picking up the first part of the motion of the honourable member for Cowper, I want to recognise the valuable and significant contribution made to world science by Australian Antarctic expeditions.

There is something of a touch of irony in the simple fact that I represent an electorate that is totally different from Antarctica in all senses. My electorate is both hot and dry. Antarctica is not recognised by most people as a dry place. Currently gripping my electorate is a certain obsession with whether or not it is going to rain. The information as to whether or not it is going to rain in much of southern Australia is probably held in the ice core of Antarctica. Much of the scientific and meteorological work that is being done in Antarctica will have a major impact on the Australian climate. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I start, I want to recognise that in the gallery today is Peter Milton, who was the chairman of the committee on which he and I travelled to Antarctica. We were both intimately involved in the Madrid protocol. So, Peter: good on you. I am glad you made it here today. I will read from Mawson's diaries. I thought that would epitomise Australian explorers. In 1912, 82 years ago, on 9 May—it was a Thursday—Mawson wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: Wind between 2 am and 6 am—40 mph. Afterwards 20 mph. Sky now clear.

PARA.TAB: We cleared the ropes about the wireless masts and intended substituting wire rope for the hemp but blizzard quickened so that we could do nothing after noon. When sending Murphy up in a boatswain's chair the rope broke.
Found the dogs had been ill-treating seals, so shall be locked up in future.
We take up trap and net, get fish in latter, worm in former is left in.
Thick drift began in the evening and wind very violent.

SPEECH.PARA: To give a little bit of his flavour, I refer to some of the other writings of Mawson. He wrote:

PARA.TAB: For many days now . . . Xavier's condition has prevented us from going on and now I am afraid it has cooked my chances altogether, even of a single attempt either to the coast or the Hut—lying in the damp bag for a week on extremely low rations has reduced my condition seriously. However, I shall spend today remodelling the gear to make an attempt. I shall do my utmost to the last for Paquita's & supporters' & members of expedition's sakes, and at least get word through how matters stand.
This spot is only a hundred miles SE of Hut—a few miles nearer, probably on slopes of icy plateau over the larger glacier past the crater.

SPEECH.PARA: Sun gleamed early in morning then got stronger. Wind however so strong, about 45 to 50 m per h, that I dare not take down tent as could not get it up again by myself; so do odd jobs waiting for a chance. I have more to eat today in hope that it will give me strength for the future. One annoying effect of want of food is that wherever the skin breaks it refused to heel, the nose and lips break open also. My scrotum, like Xavier's, is also getting in a painfully raw condition due to reduced condition, dampness and friction in walking. Is well nigh impossible to treat.

PARA.TAB: I read the Burial Service over Xavier this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: The note for 10 January reads:
No sun, heavy . . . drift, so I decided not to move but mend burberries, shovel, etc.
I will now read an extract from 17 January which states:

PARA.TAB: There had been no sun during the morning until it gleamed for a while just after the accident. Light extremely bad and only by great strain on eyes could I keep a course. I escaped several large open crevasses by Providence, not seeing them till past them, grazing one end or on top of them. `I blundered blindly on.' Then went up a long, fairly steep slope thickly covered with snow, sinking half way to knees . . . A few moments later I was dangling on end of rope in crevasse, sledge creeping to mouth. I had time to say to myself `So this is the end', expecting every moment the sledge to crash on my head and both of us to go to the bottom unseen below. Then I thought of the food left uneaten in the sledge—and, as the sledge stopped without coming down, I thought of Providence again giving me a chance. The chance looked very small as the rope had sawed into the overhanding lid, my finger ends all damaged, myself weak and as it had been warm day I had taken off most clothing and left rest very open—all now filled with snow and fingers fast chilling. With the feeling that Providence was helping me I made a great struggle, half getting out, then slipping back again several times, but at last just did it. Then I felt grateful to Providence. I was wet and cold and overcome, so decided to put up a tent.

It is impossible to say what is ahead, for the light gives no chance, and I sincerely hope that something will happen to change the state of the weather—else how am I to keep up my average. I trust in Providence, however, who has so many times already helped me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the unusual step of speaking in this debate because of the significance of the motion before the House, moved by the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) recognises the valuable and significant contribution made to world science by Australia's Antarctica expeditions; and
(2) celebrates . . . the 40th anniversary of the establishment of an Australian base at Mawson.

I have chosen to speak at the urging of the honourable member for Cowper and other backbench members because not many members of the parliament have had the opportunity to go to Antarctica that I, the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), Peter Milton and many others had.

PARA.TAB: I concede to the House that I probably did help lower the fuel bill of the Icebird on this journey, as I leant across the stern railing being violently ill most mornings in a way that I have never been sick before or since.

Going to Antarctica was the experience of a lifetime and allowed us to reflect on some of the diary entries of Mawson and to begin to understand the extent of the personal agony and courage that Mawson, Phillip Law and so many others displayed in the cause of science and understanding our planet earth—and in the cause of research in a range of areas.

Australia has four permanent bases there: Macquarie Island, Mawson, Davis and Casey. It was the Casey station that we visited in 1986. I am probably the only party leader to have visited that area. I hope others will take up that challenge. By doing so we start to understand the range of linkages and interconnection between Australia and that continent.

The scientific endeavour of the Australian Antarctica division includes the examination of the biological science area, atmospheric and space-related issues, glaciology in some detail—and medical research as well. In saluting those involved in our efforts on that great continent to the south, I especially salute those who, over winter each year—from April to October—in the cause of science in effect are locked in at Mawson, Davis and Casey in those extreme conditions. I hope that when this Hansard is relayed to them at some stage they will read that both sides of the parliament join in extending a greeting to those with that dedicated commitment which has seen Australians carrying out their work and scientific endeavours in 1994 and all other winters.

It is in that regard that I highlight to the House that a lot of the frontal systems of our weather pattern originate around the edge of the Antarctic continent. Katabatic winds descend from the South Pole. In many places the ice mass is higher than 10,000 feet. It is quite high even near the coast, such as the Law Dome, which is named after Phillip Law, a distant relative of my wife, Judy. It has now been drilled for the information going back through thousands of years that can be gained on the various layers of the Law Dome.

Those katabatic winds sweep out to sea and then start to swirl in a way which creates a series of low systems which, in turn, create the south-west fronts that the honourable member for Wakefield and other members have referred to. The import of the weather pattern on southern Australia is real, and that is why we need more research and monitoring.

It is our hope and prayer, as we speak this day, that there might well be a fair dinkum south-west front in the making. Much of southern and eastern, and even southern and western, Australia is slipping back into drought. It is a very serious dry period which will jeopardise much of the recovery if it is not abated.

In fact, it was John Mountford who travelled with us on our trip. Peter Milton went on another trip with Ian Cameron and others. A lot of very hard work goes on in Antarctica in the cause of science and the cause of a better understanding of the ecology of our planet, weather patterns and the like. It is entirely appropriate that Australia's outstanding effort over four decades, along with that of many other countries which have made a direct and indirect contribution to the knowledge of mankind, be recognised by this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the motion moved by the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl). I commend the photographic exhibition. I also commend the honourable member for Cowper for his work this morning when the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Snowdon) launched the exhibition.

PARA.TAB: I do not think there was much debate about the decision to name Australia's first station on Antarctica after Sir Douglas Mawson, because his career in exploration and science speaks for itself. It started in 1907 when he was a member of the Shackleton expedition. My first interest in Antarctica was excited when I received a school prize about the Shackleton expedition which contained a lot of photographs taken by Frank Hurley. Mawson reached the South Magnetic Pole. He climbed Mount Erebus and published observations relating to mineralogy, terrestrial magnetism and a wide range of other subjects. He headed south again in 1911 as leader of the largely Australian expedition at that time to Cape Denison, which is one of the windiest places on earth, although the honourable member for Cowper and I went to a pretty windy place on Heard Island. Who can but wonder and feel inspired by the epic journey of lone survival which Mawson endured after the death of his two companions, Mertz and Ninnis, and by the privation endured during a second winter there?

The advancement of science and exploration were the foremost tasks confronting the expedition. He mapped more than 1,500 kilometres of coast, probed 500 kilometres inland and gathered a lot of scientific data. He was knighted in 1914 and had his book, the Home of the Blizzard, a classic of polar literature, published. He led two expeditions to Antarctica between 1929 and 1931. The literature describes them as cruises, but some of us know that there is no such thing as cruising in Antarctic waters, as has been mentioned by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer). We travelled for some time at the rate of half a knot. The former member for La Trobe, Peter Milton, who I think is still in the House, was rescued by a Soviet ship when he was stuck travelling at naught for too long.

The honourable member for Cowper and I were caught in pretty terrible circumstances, being confronted with 20-metre waves. The ship was rolling 45 degrees each way. If it had rolled 60 degrees, then it would have gone upside down. It certainly was not a cruise. We lost some 20 drums of fuel. We also lost quite a lot of equipment, which we saw go overboard. It was rather a tense time; certainly not a cruise.

Mawson, after his active involvement, was involved with the establishment of the Australian National Antarctic Research Expedition in 1947 and was chairman of the national committee on Antarctic research. The Mawson station was established on 13 February 1954. It consisted of simple huts and support buildings. It was a base. It was a home and a workplace of sorts. It was from there that we established Australian pre-eminence in glaciology, physics and biology. Two other stations were built—Casey and Davis. Mawson, Casey and Davis were rebuilt and modernised in the 1980s. We have the new Mawson station.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thanks to the public works committee.

—That is right. As the honourable member for Throsby says, it is thanks to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works. He knows what it is all about, having been down there. This year the new Mawson celebrates its 40th anniversary. That is really great. Those of us who went down there know that the privations are not only being there, but also getting there and getting back. All sorts of things can happen. The people there learn to walk a different way; they have to. We even had a poetry night, and 30 people turned up to read poetry. That shows that all sorts of things can happen on a boat trip to Antarctica when there is no television. But it is with great pleasure—and I thank the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) for making way for me today—that I support the motion of the honourable member for Cowper.
