SPEECH.SPEAKER: Horne Mr R.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)expresses its opposition to the accelerated rate of indiscriminate development in coastal regions;
(2)expresses its concern at the inability of the States to enact and maintain uniform policies that maintain the integrity of this environmentally sensitive zone;

(3)calls upon, as a matter of urgency, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories to convene a meeting with all State Ministers for the Environment with a view to the establishment of a suitable national policy to safeguard our coastal heritage; and
(4)calls for a moratorium by all States on the rezoning and subdivision of land within one kilometre of the coastline until a suitable policy has been determined.

It is with the greatest sense of urgency that I move this private member's motion today. It is with urgency because, despite the increasing number of studies carried out on Australia's coastline, our most precious heritage is being degraded and destroyed at a rapidly accelerated rate. There is no greater tribute to our ignorance than the monuments we have created in coastal Australia. We have all seen them, and we should all share in the shame of their existence. They range from the relatively small civil constructions to unprecedented engineering blunders such as breakwaters along estuary mouths for a shipping trade that no longer exists, but they are structures that have changed the course of rivers, the coastline and adjacent beaches to their detriment. Of course, there is the plethora of ocean outfalls for sewage that pour enormous volumes of land-derived wastes and all the soluble nutrients and toxins of a modern, industrialised society into the ocean.

PARA.TAB: Our coastal landscape is obscured by high-rise buildings that capture the view—and damn everyone else's! The mangrove wetlands have been killed and filled, often with garbage, so that a golf course, perhaps, could be built. Coastal roads that have been carved into cliff faces have accelerated erosion as well as created traffic congestion. Sand mines have raped our beaches of heavy metals and have left a legacy of bitou bush and other imported plants.

We have had decades of piecemeal encroachment. Why? It is because we are lovers of the sea. The suntanned Aussie surfer is an international symbol that characterises our aspirations. The coast is where most Australians want to live; where there is the greatest growth; where the grab for land is taking place—be it wetland, sand dune or headland. The development of our coastline must be very profitable judging by the glossy brochures advertising, `Your last opportunity for a place in the sun.' Yet it is profit for the few and a loss for the nation as a whole.

Part of the area which I represent has been dubbed `a blue water wonderland' by the local council—indeed, it is. A total of 330,000 tourists visited Port Stephens last year and spent $1.3 million. They come in increasing numbers to enjoy its magnificent water sports: its swimming, boating and fishing. The local economy thrives on the Port Stephens festival, the big game fish competition, which is the biggest in the world, and the myriad of spin-offs that tourism brings to the area; yet the Port Stephens council has currently approved a development against the wishes of local residents. It will allow a magnificent stand of trees, estimated to be over 200 years of age, to be bulldozed and land to be filled by up to two metres of sand so that all building sites will be above the required AHD level. The local Aboriginal Land Council has claimed it as a sacred women's birth site. It is a unique living laboratory and an avifauna haven.

Local government does not have the resources and most councillors do not have the expertise. Too often they see development as offering a promise of income for urgently needed infrastructure in their own patch. They are bullied, even threatened and hoodwinked, by the glossy environmental impact statements that boast the name of a supposedly reputable firm of environmental scientists which has been consulting with the developer all along on how to get a successful result from council.

At Fern Bay, a rezoning application may see a town of 15,000 people established on a fragile dune formation. The development would raise the water table by 1.7 metres, and the effluent from the on-site sewage treatment works will be injected into the frontal dunes in an effort to stabilise them.

Seaview Gardens estate is a typical example of the wrong way to develop a coastline. This headland has high slopes and currently has excellent vegetation cover, but it has no structured soil; it is merely sand covering rock. If the vegetation goes, the sand will go with it. Who owns it? A Sydney family company with a silent Hong Kong partner. They are not developers; they are simply investors looking for a quick DA from council, a fast buck—and to hell with the environment.

Certainly, in 1990 the New South Wales government put forward a draft coastal policy, but incredibly this did not include Sydney, Newcastle or Wollongong, which were in the `too hard' basket. Yet this is the largest conglomeration of humanity in Australia, with the highest levels of pollution and coastal degradation.

It is imperative that the federal government take the lead. What must happen is a moratorium on all coastal development until we have in place a policy for sustainable development. It must involve local government, state government and federal government, which must come up with a set of non-negotiable guidelines that have been established with environmental control as the dominant underlying theme.

We must cease the practice of developers being allowed to provide their own environmental impact statements. We must ensure that when any zoning is made it is given a specific period—preferably a maximum of three to five years. We must identify land use zones and a sequence for the release of new areas. Transport infrastructure corridors must be identified now for long-term planning—perhaps a 100-year plan. Buffer zones need to be identified and their integrity guaranteed. We cannot suffer a repeat of the `fill the wetlands, they only breed mosquitoes' mentality. Any land that is earmarked for development must satisfy stringent criteria of topography, flora and fauna value to the region, the potential for erosion, heritage value and recreational amenity. Land must be identified now that will never be developed.

I have received unsolicited support from dozens of community groups throughout Australia. These include the Tasmanian Conservation Trust, the marine and coastal community network, the Newcastle Wilderness Society, the North Coast Environment Council and the Queensland Conservation Council.

Only this morning I was contacted by a planning officer who recently resigned from a coastal council because he could not stand by and watch approval being given to the subdivision of prime koala habitat without advertising first or retaining environmental protection. How long do environmentally responsible people have to ring alarm bells?

Much of what I say has been said before. In April 1991, the government accepted every recommendation of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts The injured coastline: protection of the coastal environment, including the need for a national coastal zone management strategy. It distresses me that in the three years since not only has nothing been done, but our injured coastline has been wounded again and again. We can only hope that the wounds do not prove to be mortal.

I would like to thank those on both sides of the parliament who are supporting this private member's motion. I am aware that 40 minutes is not a long time to discuss this matter of great urgency in our national parliament. I have approached the Selection Committee and I will ensure that this matter stays on the agenda. I will give a copy of my speech to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner, urging action immediately.

I would like all those who are listening to understand that, in the short time that I have spoken, 7,000 litres of primary treated effluent in the Sydney metropolitan area has flowed into the ocean in a completely untreated manner. That is the regard we have for our coastal environment.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—When I saw this motion on the Notice Paper last week, it was with a great deal of interest that I put my name down to speak. As was the case with the honourable member for Paterson (Mr Horne), I have been involved in local government on the mid north coast of New South Wales for a number of years, representing an area that has experienced a great deal of growth at a fairly rapid rate. I have also been involved in a number of fairly contentious developmental decisions concerning the coastline and in a number of exercises in local government whereby we have had to restore damage that had been done by previous development and protect development that had been put at risk by poor planning in years gone by.

PARA.TAB: This is a very complicated and complex issue. The honourable member for Paterson has addressed a number of different issues in his motion. While I agree with some aspects, I certainly disagree with others.

The first point in the motion before the House is that coastal development is accelerating and is indiscriminate. It is certainly accelerating, but I do not believe all coastal development is indiscriminate. I am sure that the honourable member for Paterson, with his local government background, would probably agree that times have been changing, albeit slowly, in the attitude of some developers to development along the coast. The development can be done in a balanced fashion, taking into account the environmental concerns that we continue to face.

I agree with some of his remarks relating to the bodies that are damaging the coastal environment. We had the opportunity to experience the doggedness of the bureaucracy through the augmentation of a sewerage treatment works in the local government area I represented some years ago. I, and another fellow who was representative of the grazing community, fought long and hard for almost two years to establish a dry land disposal system in one of the town areas in that council area.

We kept on running up a lane and into brick walls because it was not an acceptable practice to the engineers involved, the public works department. Since then, I believe, they have changed their attitude to a certain extent. But certainly it was not a viable option as far as they were concerned at the time.

So it is not just the developers and it is not just state government; the professionals in many of the bureaucracies around Australia are not prepared to contemplate lateral thinking or change. So let us not blame it all on the developers. Today we are seeing more and more developers who are prepared to consider the environmental impact. I agree with the honourable member for Paterson that from time to time the environment is paid only lip-service in regard to the environmental impact studies that have to be done. Certainly you can get a study written whichever way you want. On the other side of the coin, opponents to development can get environmental impact statements done the way they want. Whoever is paying the fee will get the report tilted in that way.

It was extremely difficult in local government as far as planning was concerned when two fairly eminent professionals in a particular area held diametrically opposed views on what impact there was going to be on the environment with a particular development. It became very onerous for the average person representing local government in making these decisions.

Let us not brand all coastal development as derogatory to the environment, or as indiscriminate. It is changing. The Commonwealth has a role to play, albeit not in an overriding sense. We should be working with the states. If we are to create a national policy, it certainly should be implemented by way of state legislation. That is if we are going to stick with the view—that I think still prevails—that land use decisions and legislation and planning decisions and legislation should remain with the states. I know that they probably vary around Australia, but certainly in New South Wales at the moment the New South Wales government's coastal policy controls to a certain extent development within that one-kilometre zone and requires an environmental study prior to rezoning.

I was not aware, as the honourable member for Paterson informed the House, that this does not include Newcastle, Sydney and Wollongong. The impact on the coastal environment in those areas is probably more to do with sewage outfalls—not so much sandmining. The coastal strips are probably more highly developed as far as residential areas are concerned than other parts of New South Wales. When considering rezonage within that one-kilometre area it should be borne in mind that it takes in a fair slice of what is already developed. Some of the urban areas in my electorate, like Forster Tuncurry, Port Macquarie, the Camden Haven area and Harrington now would wholly and solely fall within that one-kilometre zone. So I suppose it is something we should be mindful of, but let us not lose sight of the fact—and I am not here defending the New South Wales government—that that policy does exist at the moment. It is incumbent on local government authorities to be aware of that. It is a key criterion. I know it is a key criterion in the local environment plan in the Manning and Great Lakes areas.

Going back to the point I was making, if we are going to have a national policy on coastal development, my firm belief is that it must be implemented by state legislation. The states must maintain control of planning in these coastal areas. Whilever we believe in the federal system and conduct a federal system throughout the Commonwealth we must maintain the states' right to the planning controls over land use and not centralise that power here in Canberra, which is far more remote from the individual circumstances in those areas.

In the third part of the motion of the honourable member for Paterson he talks about the consultative aspect in regard to national policy where the Commonwealth minister and state ministers can get together. He is talking about the ministers for the environment, but I think that should also include the ministers who have responsibility in the planning areas because they really go hand in hand. If we are going to establish environmental aspects of planning they must be implemented in conjunction with the planning department. Certainly my understanding is that in New South Wales state environmental planning policy is policed by the planning department.

There should be not only environment ministers but also planning ministers involved in that consultative process. If they reach final agreement on a national policy, it should be implemented via state legislation, not Commonwealth legislation.

The moratorium on all rezoning in subdivisions of land within one kilometre of the coast concerns me a little. In New South Wales, if there is an application for a parcel of land to be rezoned within that one kilometre coastal strip, then there has to be an environmental study attached to the rezoning application. In the planning process for these sorts of issues, where we say we are going to have a moratorium on development of subdivisions, we may lose sight of the fact that someone in the recent past may have purchased land with a reasonable expectation of being able to develop it on the basis of the way it is zoned today. To set an arbitrary date that eliminates the ability of that person who has invested probably quite a lot of money into that parcel of land because of the zoning is something that we have to examine very carefully.

It has happened that local government bodies have implemented changes in planning policy and said, `Today is the day. You were there yesterday. Bad luck. You have dipped out to the tune of a couple of hundred thousand dollars. Tomorrow we start afresh.' That is not fair. We need to be very careful how that form of moratorium may be introduced. I tend to agree with a moratorium on rezoning, but certainly we need to be very careful in the case of the subdivision of land that has already been rezoned to a certain use. Not everybody can afford such a loss. They are not all big time developers with overseas connections. Quite often we are talking about people who may have taken a redundancy package from their long-time place of employment. They have invested in a small parcel of land in area that may be developed into a residential type development with no impact on the local area. We must be very careful that we do not discriminate against those people. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, I make another reference to the former member for La Trobe, Mr Milton, who was the chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts when that committee started an inquiry into the coastal zone in 1989. I recall visiting many places. I know that report was handed down in 1991, but I am saddened to hear that very little has happened since. However, some things have happened, and I will mention them during my speech.

PARA.TAB: I am very pleased to support this motion, which I am sure will create a controversy. However, I believe it should be supported to draw attention to the rapid degradation of our magnificent coastline. Our coast has been described very succinctly in the report of the coastal zone inquiry produced in November 1993. The overview said:

SPEECH.PARA: The coastal zone has a special place in the lives of Australians. Most Australians want to live there and if they can't they want to take their holidays there. It contains diverse ecosystems and a high proportion of Australia's industrial activity occurs in the zone. It is a priceless national resource.

Australia's coastal zone is more than a national asset. It is irreplaceable capital. We should strive to pass this capital on to the next generation undiminished. From it we ourselves derive the interest on which we live and depend. If our forebears had known what we know now, and had not squandered what they did, the returns to us today would be higher than they are. The strain in the coastal zone shows we are continuing to eat away at the capital, at precisely the time we need it most. What is worse, we have been too often unaware of doing it, until the consequences have become too obvious to miss, and the risks to our future impossible to ignore.

It is time for us to become aware. It is time for us to act before it is too late. The average growth rate of Australia's east coast strip in November 1993 was 1.9 per cent—almost double the national average of 1.1 per cent. Close to nine out of 10 Australians live in the zone, but since the 1970s there has been a profound shift in where they live.

PARA.TAB: Almost half of Australia's total population growth in the past two decades has been in the non-metropolitan coastal zone. This growth in the zone is far from fully understood. Economic development, an ageing population, growth in tourism and associated industry, as well as changing social values, clearly are important factors. So too are government policies affecting retirement income, social welfare and taxation. Policies promoting the decentralisation of industry must also be included.

Necessary data from the 1991 census, which would allow a detailed analysis of the causes of this mass migration away from the cities and towards the coast, is not yet available. The point is, however, that the trend is set to continue. That is the assessment of the Australian Bureau of Statistics for the period to the year 2005 at least. By comparison with what we have witnessed to date, the impact on towns, cities and the environment generally will be proportionately greater. By 2005 almost one million additional people probably will be living in the non-metropolitan coastal zone.

Two factors are likely to impose particular strains. One is that the areas of greatest growth in the past are likely to continue to grow as strongly as before. These areas are principally in south-east and North Queensland, coastal New South Wales, south-east Melbourne and the areas immediately north and south of Perth. An almost uninterrupted ribbon of urbanisation is fast developing from the south coast of New South Wales right up to Hervey Bay, Queensland. The beginnings of a similar phenomenon are apparent in North Queensland. The Albert Shire, which links Brisbane to the Gold Coast, is the nation's fastest growing municipality. Since 1976 its annual population growth has averaged 11.8 per cent.
I have collected just one or two examples of news items from the past few weeks which demonstrate the type of thing that is happening. The West Australian Sunday Times of 1 May 1994 stated:
A scramble to develop along the spectacular Leeuwin-Naturaliste ridge is ringing alarm bells throughout WA.
A population explosion in South-West resort towns, including Margaret River and Busselton, has added to the pressure from investors after prime land between Cape Naturaliste and Cape Leeuwin.
People in the region held a special electors' meeting at Margaret River this month and called for a moratorium on all housing subdivisions in the Augusta-Margaret River shire, west of Caves Road.

A spokesman for the groups, Peter Warrilow, said if the development went ahead it could open the floodgates for development along the ridge. "This block could set a precedent for what is going to happen to the rest of the ridge. There are many proposals in the pipeline," he said.
Hundreds of signatures have been obtained from visitors to Hamelin Bay opposed to development.

SPEECH.PARA: In the weekend insert this weekend I saw this ad:

"Quarterdeck, Batemans Bay, 4 magnificent houses now selling, spectacular panoramic ocean and beach views from every room, absolutely no public access, private fully landscaped cliff top gardens, two minutes nature walk to beach."

This ad shows a point with four houses on it. There is absolutely no public access. This is the sort of thing that is happening all around our coast at the moment. In Frankston, where I come from, down in Flinders there are private beaches. The public is not allowed on them; they are owned by someone and no-one can get to them. Of course, the public cannot get around Sydney Harbour because of private ownership. An article which appeared in my local paper recently stated:
Shire of Flinders councillors fear the proposed State Government Coastal and Bay Management Council is merely going to provide an extra layer of bureaucracy.
This is the fear of local government. I believe local councils do not have the expertise to make the informed correct decisions about our coast. The coastal zone inquiry has proposed:

. . . the enactment of a Commonwealth Coastal Resource Management Act. This Act would incorporate the objectives and principles for coastal management agreed by the Commonwealth, by the States and by Local Government. By the very fact of its enactment, the Coastal Resource Management Act would underline the importance of the Coastal Zone in the scheme of national affairs, and give it due recognition.

It has proposed nine objectives: coastal zone resources should be available for fair and equitable public and commercial use; consequences arising from the highly dynamic nature of coastal environments should be recognised and acted upon; public access to the coast should be maintained; areas and features of significant ecological, physical, cultural, indigenous, historic, landscape and scientific importance should be conserved; the biological diversity of marine and terrestrial ecosystems should be maintained; the quality of coastal waters should be maintained; informed public participation should be ensured; indigenous interests in the coastal zone should be recognised and incorporated into management arrangements; and understanding of coastal zone ecosystems and natural processes and the effects on them of human activities should be enhanced. These are very worthy objectives and should be implemented as soon as possible.

PARA.TAB: To fund the implementation of these objectives, taxes, levies, development fees and other financial instruments should be introduced to make certain that there is enough money to buy back privately owned coastal properties and rehabilitate that which is degraded. Already the objections are starting. This is part of a letter I have received:

SPEECH.PARA: I am writing to you as a member of the Federal Government in relation to the recent recommendation from the Coastal Zone Inquiry to encourage State taxes on coastal hotels. This recommendation is ill-advised and will have extremely serious ramifications for the tourism industry.

I believe that there are many meetings going on right now between state and federal governments to reach an agreed position regarding our coastal zone. Community groups, local, state and federal governments all have a responsibility to the people of our nation. Their duty is to obtain a decision with which we can all be satisfied, and that decision is the proper management of this priceless asset.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr E.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak to the motion of the honourable member for Paterson (Mr Horne), for the thrust of the motion impacts significantly on my electorate of Stirling, which, for the record, encompasses the best beaches in the world. I have mixed feelings about this motion. On the one hand, there are coastal developments which I am not opposed to, and within my own electorate I point out the Observation City resort as an example of a positive development which has benefited the area. On the other hand, there are examples of development for development's sake, and again within my own electorate I point out the Trigg bushland as an example of where development was proposed but which was quite stupid and totally unnecessary. It is quite incomprehensible as to why it was thought of in the first place. I would like to expand on these two different examples—one a positive development, the other an unnecessary one—to illustrate the point.

PARA.TAB: Observation City resort is a major hotel complex on Scarborough beach, one of the most popular beaches in Western Australia and a retreat for many tourists within Western Australia, the eastern states and overseas. It has created many jobs within my electorate; it has earned tourist income for our state and many local businesses within my electorate. One of my only regrets is that the complex itself is foreign owned. Nonetheless, the development of Observation City was a definitely positive move and one that I have always been proud to support.

I should also add that there was a great suspicion surrounding the approval process with Observation City, and it was, of course, linked to the scandals of WA Inc. While it is regretted that the development was tainted by suggestions of corruption, wrongdoing and ill-conceived motives, my support for the development of Observation City is in-principle support. I would like it placed on the record that, whilst the somewhat dubious approvals which enabled the Bond Corporation to be granted the right to build Observation City should be questioned, the actual development itself has my support.

I must also note that there were some concerns about the development with regard to the fact that Observation City interfered with television reception. That is more a planning fault than anything else and should have been overcome during the building of the resort, but the development should not have been opposed for that reason.

In a speech made by Mr Ric Charlesworth, the former member for Perth, in 1991 on a report by the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts—of which I and the honourable member for Paterson are members—he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We—
the committee when on one of its meetings—

started off, of course, at Scarborough Beach. If one stands on the beach in Western Australia, one can look as far as one wants north or south and see beautiful white sands and lovely blue water. Unfortunately, the one thing that obscures one's vision is that monolith at Scarborough, Observation City, a testament to the forces of evil.

The former member never questioned the impact on the environment this development had, and I am not aware of any damage to the environment that it has caused—that is, I doubt that any damage occurred. It is certainly not an eyesore, though I understand it did disturb the views of some neighbours to the resort. This development, it should be noted, has enabled not just the people of Stirling but the people from the lesser states east of the Sandy Desert and tourists from overseas to enjoy and appreciate the beautiful white sands and lovely blue water referred to by Mr Charlesworth.

PARA.TAB: To relate this development to the motion of the honourable member for Paterson, I would suggest it is not an indiscriminate development and that we should not assume that because one wishes to develop land on or near a beachfront it is environmental vandalism ensconced in scandal and should be opposed. We should provide serious consideration to all such developments and not write them off without any consideration. Nevertheless, I still sympathise with his motion and agree that we do need uniform policies which will maintain the precious environmental aspects of the coastal regions of our nation. We must safeguard these regions—indeed planning policies must consider the impact on the environment wherever development takes place whether it is on the coast or deep within our vast land mass—but we should not oppose all development under the guise of it being environmentally unfriendly.

That is why a uniform policy is required, but I do not think that in the interim—until a policy is developed—a moratorium on the rezoning and subdivision of land within one kilometre of the coastline is a suitable action, particularly in view of the time it often takes for such decisions to be made. In this case it would require agreement between the environment ministers of all states plus, I would suggest, our planning ministers as well as local government ministers and then the cooperation of local government. In fact, this last point that coastal management needs to jointly involve federal, state and local government was—it has been pointed out to me—recently noted by Justice Stewart.

Nevertheless, in the interim, we do require responsible decision making and certainly not the rash develop-at-all-cost ideas that have permeated government authorities in different areas of the country, which have consequently devalued many beautiful areas of coastland. While development should be allowed it must proceed with caution and the second and third parts of this motion should allow for that, though, I repeat, I do not think that a moratorium is particularly necessary.

I mentioned previously another area of my electorate, the Trigg beach bushland, which was proposed to be developed but thankfully commonsense has prevailed and the development has been abandoned. There is quite a difference between this and the Observation City development in that the Trigg development should have involved major site works, the destruction of considerable natural vegetation, and alteration to the natural dune landscape to create artificial depressions and so-called green spaces. Such environmental damage did not occur with the Observation City development. In fact, before Observation City there was an establishment in Scarborough right in that very area known as the snake pit, and that pretty much described the entire run-down beachfront area at the time.

The Trigg bushland was a good idea which went over the top. There were some alterations which were probably necessary and would have been welcomed, such as an upgrade to the nearby car park and toilet facilities, coupled with a revegetation program. However, what eventually developed was a master plan which went well beyond the original proposals and would have been quite destructive to the local environment. These examples do show a need, as the motion of the honourable member for Paterson urges, for nationwide uniform environmental and planning policies. We certainly do not want another Gold Coast, which was an excessive abuse of our coastal region. However, the likes of Observation City and the Hillarys Marina, which is further north in the electorate of the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing), are worthy developments which I have no qualms about.

In speaking directly to the motion, I do not think there has been excessive and indiscriminate development in the coastal regions of Western Australia. I do agree with the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) when he said that we have to remain vigilant on this. I can agree that other parts of Australia have suffered from irresponsible decision making but a moratorium would not fix the problem; only the introduction of responsible planning and environmental policies would. As the motion indicates, it would be best if these laws were uniform across the nation.

I am in total agreement with the second and third points of the motion. I respectfully suggest that our committee—that is, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts—look further into coastal development policies and, in particular, the possibility of forming nationwide uniform environmental and planning policies.

Finally, I concur with the third point—that all environment ministers, state and federal, should meet as a matter of some urgency. I also suggest that we should include state planning and local government ministers, for they also have responsibility in this area. While I have reservations about some points of the motion, I certainly concur with the thrust of it and I commend the honourable member for Paterson for bringing this very important and topical issue to the attention of the House. This government accepted the report on our wounded coast in 1991. This report has already been referred to by the honourable member for Paterson, yet it has not been acted on. I pose this question: why not? Now is the time to do something about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House supports:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)majority Australian ownership of the Australian National Line;
(2)Australian flagged and Australian crewed vessels operating under Australian awards; and
(3)cabotage on the Australian coastline.

As an island nation, Australia is more dependent on shipping than most other nations for imports and exports. It is a scandal that so little of our trade is carried in Australian flagged and crewed vessels. Indeed, 96 per cent of our external trade is carried in foreign flag vessels. But it would be an even greater scandal if the Australian National Line were sold off. It would also be economic folly—economic folly because the world's fleet is ageing. People today are not building ships and, even if a start were made today, in eight to 10 years there would be a shortage of ships and trained personnel to work on these ships. Instead of talking about selling off Australian shipping, this House should be urging the building of more Australian ships. I give the commitment here that I will continue to work to ensure that the ANL is left intact and to have the shipping line Australian owned, Australian flagged, Australian crewed and under Australian regulations and award conditions.

PARA.TAB: Governments have made very poor political decisions in regard to the ANL. The Hawke Labor government pledged a $100 million grant to recapitalise ANL in 1989. The money was to allow ANL to restructure and purchase new vessels. ANL had to enter into complex financial arrangements, including the sale of vessels to keep afloat when the government stopped the grant. The construction of one vessel, River Tamar, began at Carrington Slipways in Newcastle. After the shipyard went into receivership, a further $10 million capital injection was promised to complete the River Tamar, but it never eventuated.

More than a decade ago, the ANL was on its knees but the government would not write off the debt. It decided to convert the loans to government equity in ANL. Since 1983 the Commonwealth has invested $100 million in ANL. In return, the employees and management have increased the net worth of the company by $450 million. Australian seafarers have been committed to ANL and industry reform. The Maritime Union of Australia helped make the line more efficient and viable. It did this to keep the national shipping industry afloat. It saw Australian crews reduced to below OECD levels, it has multiskilled and has been at the forefront of national reconstruction.

ANL is extremely important because we Australians own it. The Australian people own it; it is our shipping line. Without an Australian National Line, we are in the hands of overseas interests. The asset sales task force is methodically stripping away our heritage, our wealth and, I believe, the control Australian people have over our economic future. It has sold viable enterprises to people whose only interest is self-interest, at great cost to the national economy.

It is selling off assets that give wealth back to the people. The task force consists of and is advised by economic rationalists. Privatisation looks good to them and opens up plenty of consultancy work for the advisers. Australia is left with the damage bill. ANL has 14 ships. It employs between 700 and 800 seafarers. The National Line covers the key world trades of Asia and Europe. It is Australia's largest employer in overseas trade.

If ANL is privatised, the 14 ships will go as well as the 800 seafarers. We have to rebuild ANL. It is in our national interests to do so. In 1928, the Bruce government gave away our Commonwealth line for a song. It must not happen again. ANL provides important net balance of payments benefits that would be lost if it were taken over by a foreign shipping line.

The national interest requires that Australia maintains an adequate supply of shipping to keep the country going during times of national emergency, be they trade wars or military conflicts. We in Australia spend over $7 billion per year on the carriage of our imports and exports, with a net cost of $2 billion to the balance of payments. The sale of ANL would give away our seat at the conference tables around the world to foreign owned, multinational self-interests.

Australia is at the end of the world shipping lines. The sale of ANL would effectively give away the control of these economic lifelines. ANL is a key player in the world shipping scene, protecting our economic rights. It provides important maritime skills, management and marketing expertise that would be lost with any sale to overseas interests. Australian National Line is the only international sea carrier that is based in Australia and is able to represent Australian export interests at meetings of international operators.

If we sold off ANL, the other Australian owned shipping lines would also flag out. For example, if ANL were sold to overseas interests, the BHP fleet would obviously flag out. I suggest that we would get a situation where the BHP fleet could be owned by Hong Kong interests, registered in Cyprus and flying the Cypriot flag and have Greek officers with a mixed Burmese and Filipino crew. These well-maintained and well-crewed Australian ships would decline.

The motion also mentions cabotage, so I will talk a little about it. I was one of the members of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure who brought down the report entitled Ships of shame. That report highlighted the condition of many ships coming into Australia. Yet these are the very ships that the vested interests who push for cabotage to be lifted want on Australian waters. Not only are these ships an international disgrace; they are a danger to the coastline of Australia. A number of them have become coffin ships to significant numbers of seafarers.

Despite what some honourable members opposite claim, there have been extensive and successful reforms to shipping and the waterfront in Australia in recent years. When those vocal claims for the removal of cabotage are made, we should look very hard at the calls by the vested interests, such as the Business Council of Australia, the Australian Mining Industry Council and the International Bulk Commodities Group for the relaxation of cabotage and the turning over to foreign flagged vessels of the sea link in our domestic transport chain. If this massive distortion of our economic transport chain were to occur, it would destroy forever the chance we may now have, slim though it might be, to build a truly domestic transport system. But this does not worry those who want to make a short-term quick buck.

The only difference now between Australian shipping and our foreign competitors is that many operate under flags of convenience from havens denied to Australians. Often their crews do not pay tax. If that handicap were removed by properly structuring the fiscal circumstances of the Australian shipping industry, Australian shipping would then be seen in its true light as an effective and internationally competitive activity.

Our Australian flagged ships are of a high standard. I believe that our reputation has been enhanced by the recommendations of the Ships of shame report, the majority, but not all, of which have been accepted by the government. But what will happen to that reputation if we sell our fleet? In my view, it is essential that we maintain ANL as an Australian owned, Australian flagged and Australian crewed shipping line where people are employed under Australian standards and conditions. I make no apology for saying that. I will fight with all my ability to see that this is maintained.

Are we prepared to put the future of our trade in the hands of foreign shipping interests? Make no mistake: if we sell off ANL, this is what we will be doing. As I said before, instead of talking about selling off ANL, we should be talking about investing in more Australian ships. If we are really serious about protecting the Australian maritime environment, there would be no talk of selling off ANL. We are more likely to be able to protect our environment if we are dealing with our own registered, flagged and crewed ships.

During recent years I have personally inspected much of the substandard shipping detained around Australia. Anyone who doubts the condition under which these ships sail, the condition of the ships and the condition of the crew, ought to have a look at some of these ships. Some of these conditions were highlighted in the Ships of shame report. The crews had to work under appalling conditions. They received starvation wages or sometimes no wages at all. There was a lack of food and the crews suffered physical and sexual abuse. People in ports such as Newcastle and Port Kembla will repeat these stories. If people doubt it at all, they should talk to the chaplains from the Missions of the Seamen.

My preference is for all of ANL to remain in public ownership. I do not see what this craze is to sell off everything which is under public ownership. I am an old-style socialist who believes in public ownership; I make no apology for that. A minimum should be an ANL, with majority Australian ownership and with Australian flagged and Australian crewed vessels. It should operate under Australian awards. The main operations must be in Australia. There must be a majority of Australian directors, and there must be an Australian chairperson. I am all for keeping ANL as it is—100 per cent Australian owned.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—Towards the end of his speech the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) outlined the reason for bringing this motion before the House. As he said, he is an old-time socialist and he believes in government ownership of various entities throughout the community. That is what the real basis of this motion is. There is a debate within the government about privatising ANL, and the honourable member prefers to see the Australian national shipping line remain wholly owned, 100 per cent owned, by the government. The honourable member's motion is, no doubt, really about preselection and getting support from the correct unions within his electorate. We need to be aware of the basic reason for this motion coming before the House.

PARA.TAB: Putting that aside, the first part of the motion states that this House supports majority Australian ownership of the Australian National Line. I notice that the honourable member for Throsby does not want 51 per cent Australian ownership, but 100 per cent. That is his basic starting point. That is part of the platform of the left wing faction of the government.

The coalition is very supportive of Australians owning shipping lines around Australia—not just one, hopefully several. It would be good if we had competitive Australian shipping companies which are able to make a real go of it. The motion moved by the honourable member for Throsby belongs to a different era. It is an archaic way to approach shipping in this country. It goes back to the debates of the 1960s, maybe the 1950s, about how Australia should interact with the world. The fact is that we now operate in a global world community, particularly with regard to shipping. The essence of this motion is to have an Australian national line, irrespective of how good it is.

I am fully supportive of ANL being a shipping line if it is competitive and if it operates effectively. But, as the honourable member for Throsby illustrated, the government has had to pump $100 million into this operation over the last 10 years to keep it afloat. Does that really mean that we have got a shipping line which is competitive and effective? I think that is very questionable. Hopefully, ANL is now competitive. I hope and certainly desire that it is a competitive shipping line. In some respects it is. To argue in this House today that we should maintain 100 per cent ownership of the shipping line, irrespective of how good it is in its operation, is archaic.

The honourable member is saying `hands off' in regard to overseas interests. What about hands off in other areas, if that is what he wants to do? But that is not the world in which we as Australians any longer live.

We are totally interconnected with other communities and other operations around the world. As with environmental matters in this country, we live in a global and economic community. We cannot just shut our eyes to the competitive influences which are now operating in the world in this area. Let us take a positive approach on this matter. Let us have more than one shipping line which is totally Australian owned. For example, Brambles is a company which owns shipping. I would hope that a company like that, owned by Australians, could become a large shipping line around the world. Let us have other shipping lines developed; there are lots of other small operators around. We should not have a head in the sand approach that only one Australian national shipping line can be effective.

Having a more effective shipping line in Australia is not the only issue we should be addressing; we should also be addressing waterfront reform. This was touched on briefly by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Throsby. I would like to illustrate in this debate some lack of coherency in this area in government policy. The government talks about improvements in waterfront reform, which has been done largely through deregulating and changing what has been there in the past. I think it has brought about some real improvements.

In my own port of Burnie, Tasmania, the fifth largest container port in Australia, there have been some considerable improvements. Those improvements, though, have come about not by hanging on to past archaic ideas on how to do it but by moving forward. Just to illustrate, for example: all the waterside workers on the Burnie wharf are employed by the Burnie Port Authority. That authority also owns the Burnie Wynyard airport. If a ship is not in port at the time, those workers will also go out, if required, to the Burnie airport and do work out there. If there is work in the office to be done by the Burnie Port Authority, the people who work on the wharves will also go there. There is no idle time any longer. As many in this country would know, there was a time when there was a lot of idle time on our wharves.

Changes in the waterfront area have made the transport industry more competitive. With shipping, we have the idea that we can hang on to and keep a company as a national, government owned company and if it does not trade properly keep pouring money into it. That is not the way in which Australia will get exports moving around this country nor to other countries overseas. There is a lack of coherency between waterfront reform and the motion which has been moved by the honourable member for Throsby on shipping.

The government talks about having a flat playing field so that we can compete on an equal basis. I would agree with that: let us have our shipping compete on an equal basis. Let us make sure that overseas lines do not come in here with their shipping being subsidised and so undermining our shipping lines. I agree with that. However, the government has to make sure that the cost structures of shipping are not increased disproportionately with those of overseas shipping. For example, in the last budget the government increased excise by 3c a litre. That put up the cost of transporting of ships by $288,000 per vessel per year just by adding to the fuel costs. What did that mean? It meant that fuel costs for Australia's nearest shipping line competitors was 43 per cent higher and 70 per cent higher when compared with the world's best.

The government cannot have it both ways. On the one hand, we cannot have government members coming in here and saying, `Let's keep our shipping line and have a flat playing field' and, on the other hand, saying, `Let's increase excise on fuel for our shipping.' I think all of us in Australia recognise that as a nation we have to be competitive. Our shipping lines also have to be competitive. I would welcome having ANL remain as it is, if it is truly competitive. But from time to time we see that that is not necessarily the case.

This motion assumes that the government can pick winners. Why should ANL be better than any other Australian owned company operating in Australian waters? I do not believe that governments should be in the business of picking winners. What we should be doing is encouraging as many different people as possible to own ships around the Australian coastline, and to be competitive, aggressive and effective operators. This country, being an island continent, certainly needs access to shipping lanes around the world. It would be good if we controlled a lot of companies that had shipping interests.

Finally, in regard to cabotage, the previous speaker mentioned that it brought in the idea of safety—that Australia can control ships that come into Australian waters. That is the way in which we should operate. We should be exercising control. There is no reason why we should allow ships to operate within our waters without due safety provisions. As for cabotage, which enables us to keep other ships out and keep our own ships for intrastate shipping and so forth, I do not think this is the way in which Australia can go. I do not think we can hide our heads in the sand in this area. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite surprised by the ignorance shown by certain people on the other side. It has been suggested that the proposition put by the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) is archaic. It may be timely in the sense that it has some historical background and maybe we ought to go through that, but before we do, I would point out that the other day a question was asked of the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) by the honourable member for Fowler (Mr Grace) about the level of foreign aid given by this country. In his reply, the Minister for Finance suggested that one of our problems in delivering foreign aid and delivering it within our budget requirements is that only 38 per cent of our GDP is in public ownership.

PARA.TAB: He quite rightly pointed to Sweden—a Scandinavian country—which has 72 per cent of its GDP in public ownership. He talked about the foreign aid that it can give and the dollars and cents that it can throw at projects. It has no difficulty finding these dollars and cents because a high level of its GDP is in public ownership. So before people on the other side start talking about the fact that it is wrong or archaic for Australia to have public ownership of resources, I think they should look at the 1990s and the Scandinavian countries which are doing quite well with high levels of public ownership.

Let us look at the realities. The first national line was set up in World War I. It was set up because there was a strategic need for this country to recognise that we are a big island, that nothing comes into or out of Australia in great quantities unless it is by sea. I would have thought that those on the other side had realised that. Obviously, they have not. In a military sense, strategically it is ideal for the Australian government to have some control over movements into and out of our own ports.

In terms of trade, it was recognised back then that we did need to have a national carrier, someone who could protect the interests, not just of one or two rich companies, but of all Australians. That is why it was established. The honourable member for Throsby mentioned the demise of that first Australian national line during the term of the Bruce-Page government. Let us look at why the Bruce-Page government got rid of that national line.

Lo and behold, Prime Minister Bruce had vast connections with P&O! He had a great deal of trouble with the wharf unions when he could not get some of his goods on to the Christmas market. It is historically documented. Therefore, he pressed for those workers on the docks and our seamen to be forced under. The only way he could do that was by selling out our national line. He did so at a pittance. It took many years for us again to be in a position to have a national line, which we now have.

I would suggest that Australia has not moved. We happen to be exactly where we were in 1917. The water between us and Hong Kong is just as vast. The continents may have moved a millimetre, but it is nothing which will affect our position in terms of access to world markets and the ability to get vast quantities of our goods out and other goods in. Therefore, strategically in terms of trade all of the things that were mentioned by the honourable member for Throsby—being able to be involved in international shipping boards and keeping on the pulse of what is going on—are integral to our having a national line. They would be reasons enough, but there are more reasons.

The honourable member for Throsby described himself as a socialist. I also put my hand up. I do not in any way suggest that this is a dirty word. What does it mean to me? It means that I care about ordinary Australian people. I think there are some things which all of us should own. All of us should benefit from the minerals under the ground, not just foreigners or outside companies. We should all benefit from health and education. That is what socialism is about. It is not about knocking out people's ability to set up companies and go forward. It is about saying that there are certain things that all of us should benefit from. I will never resile from that. We need health, we need education and we need roofs over our heads. These things should be financed paid for by things which are collectively owned by all of us.

I will never sit in this country and be happy if what has happened in Britain happens here. Britain has tried to privatise the water, for God's sake! So if someone cannot get a drink and does not have enough bucks, that person is supposed to die. These are the ideas of unbridled capitalism, along with the idea that people can be used to the extent that they are some sort of fodder or unit. That is an archaic idea. That is the idea that should be taken out.

I would suggest that there is a world crisis in shipping. Anyone who took five minutes to find out about it, instead of standing up waffling on while knowing absolutely nothing about shipping, would know that $400 billion, if spent today, would not be enough. Australians in our gallery now do not realise! How are we going to have a push of exports to Asia if we do not have ships? The world fleet is on average 18 years of age. The recommended maximum age of a ship is 16 years.

The honourable member for Throsby talked about those rust buckets in Ships of shame. They take the majority of the world's cargo. The honourable member for Throsby and I are concerned about the seamen they take with them when they hit the bottom. That is not to mention our concern about those rust buckets going over our reef. How will Australians feel when half-rusted-out oil tankers coming down here end up on our reefs? What sorts of costs will we bear then?

If the shipping crisis is not addressed, we as an island nation are in deep trouble. We need to export to Asia. How are we going to get our exports there? Will we put on Coolite sandals and carry them? I would suggest that we need to have our own foot in the door.

Hilmer has indicated in public debates all over this country that competition policy does not give efficiency or equity in the allocation of resources. All we have to do to know that is look at Optus and Telecom. There are two sets of lines going side by side. Does that give us any more services? No, it does not. When I try to use a mobile phone in my electorate, I cannot get through. Resources would be allocated if we had efficient public-ownership and no privatisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is your policy.

—Before the honourable member for Hindmarsh, who is at the table, goes on any further, I remind her that it was her people who talked about our having archaic ideas of public ownership. So why does she not listen to her speakers before she starts ratting off?

PARA.TAB: I suggest that the next decade will be crucial. If we, as a country, do not address the urgency to look after our strategic and trade interests by having a national line, then this country has a poor future. We will be at the behest of those overseas who will control the rates and tariffs of the movement of goods and services. Think about where we were in the 1940s, folks. Would people like to be in that position again? I for one would not. I for one believe that we need to keep the core of the industry that we have on board. It is from that core that we can build a sustainable and long-term shipping industry. Of all the places in the world, this country needs it more than most. If we lose that expertise, if we lose those great people in the Maritime Union of Australia, if we lose our docks and if we lose our shipping industry, then we lose in the long term.

This country has to stand up for itself. Retaining ANL and the presence of Australian shipping is a vital concern. I cannot understand why all Australians are not up in arms about the thought of the Australian National Line being sold. Our future, our kids' future and our grandchildren's future are at stake. If we lose the Australian National Line, then it will be the beginning of the end. We will be begging and kowtowing to the rest of the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to speak in this debate. I do not think many people realise the importance of the maritime industry to Australia: it is an $8 billion industry. It is therefore important that, before we progress any further, we come to a proper understanding of where the maritime industry is going.

PARA.TAB: As I said, I am happy to speak in this debate on the motion of the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis). I wish to speak on some of the peripheral matters that should be determined within this debate, such as the government ownership of the Australian National Line. I also refer to the pool of maritime labour which is under union control and the maintenance of cabotage on our Australian shipping coastline.

I would be the first to acknowledge that, over the last 10 years, the image of the maritime unions has dramatically changed in Australia. There have been great improvements in workplace practices, ship manning levels, demarcation issues and many other conditions which in the past made the Australian shipping industry so uncompetitive and which, unfortunately, allowed Australia to drag well behind the rest of the world when it came to international shipping. As I understand it, improvements in work practices alone resulted in $217,000 per vessel being saved on that last round. When looking at our industrial situation compared with that of the rest of the world, I believe these costs are now below OECD levels.

I maintain that, in order to become internationally competitive, much more has to be done. Shipowners cannot get these productivity gains, which the government is seeking under enterprise bargaining, while the union has this pool of labour which it allocates to the industry.

Firstly, I wish to address the issue of Australian ownership. The only problem with ANL retaining its government ownership is that, as has been said, it almost has a conflict of interest; the owners of the line are the people responsible as a government for trying to provide the industrial framework to make the Australian shipping industry provide for itself. The opposition would love the ownership of the line to remain in Australian hands. But, when it comes to asking where that capital is coming from, one wonders whether those savings are available in Australia.

I noticed in the white paper prepared by the government that the airports are up for sale. Qantas is on a public float. The question is: where does one find the capital? As I said before, there has to be a change from government ownership. I wonder how the first item of the motion of the honourable member for Throsby will come into effect if we expect the majority of Australian ownership to come from the private sector.

I will give a recent example of the shortage of capital in Australia. Two abattoirs which were owned formally by Borthwicks in the Mackay and Bowen areas in my electorate were sold to Australian Meat Holdings. It was forced to sell because of a monopoly in the marketplace. It could not attract 100 per cent of Australian buyers in the first place. As I understand it, the price was as little as $30 million for the two of them. Eventually, Mackay Sugar took a 30 per cent interest, and a Japanese interest took 70 per cent. I understand that as of the last month or so it is completely Japanese owned—foreign owned—and there has been no FIRB inquiry. In the light of this, one has to wonder where that capital has come from, particularly when we know an expanding foreign debt has to be serviced and our superannuation funds are apparently closed to such investment.

I turn my attention to the matter of union crewing of ships. I think this is a vital case. There is no doubt that, while there is union crewing of ships, it has a capacity to add costs. The transfer of those crews from one port to another, travel expenses and things like that add considerably to shipping costs. There is no chance of enterprise bargaining while the companies themselves, while not employing that labour, are removed from that direct employment. In this regard, I believe it is the only industry in Australia that exercises such an archaic practice.
The second case is the Coal Industry Tribunal, which is isolationist in what it does. In the famous white paper of last week, I genuinely support this statement on page 40:

SPEECH.PARA: Negotiations on company employment in our shipping industry are being undertaken under the auspices of the Shipping Industry Reform Authority.

I give wholehearted endorsement to that. I ask, Mr Deputy Speaker, whether you, as the mover of this motion, approve of that statement, as you no doubt approve of the sale of the airports of the FAC to private enterprise.

PARA.TAB: I believe it is very important that crews are controlled by the shipping companies, particularly if we want a great Australian shipping industry—one that can have direct contact with the ship owners to get real productivity from enterprise bargaining. I think it is all the more important, particularly when the people who are paying the bills at the moment and are trying to meet international competition are not the ones who employ.

I turn to the final matter of cabotage. I believe the honourable member for Throsby has said on previous occasions that cabotage is the safety net for the industry. I do not believe it is. I think the safety net for the industry is the manner in which the Australian government controls and regulates the Navigational Act on maritime safety. It depends on those people as to whether we have a safe industry or not.

Only last week we were debating in this chamber matters that referred to the Ships of shame report, the Navigation Act and other incidents. This argument depends on how international bodies can become operative in ensuring the safety of these ships. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Knott), talked about rust buckets. The international recommended standard is a vessel no older than 16 years. The average age of ships now is about 18 years. I think it is very important that we implement international maritime law to make shipping safe, and cabotage is not the only issue.

The real issue that is not addressed by this—it surprises me—is how government charges and taxes influence the viability of our own Australian shipping industry. Bearing in mind that 94 per cent of international shipping in and out of Australia is done by international companies and not by Australian companies, one has to look at the reason why our own companies are not competing. We can look at the recent increase in the excise on fuel, which I understand raised the price of fuel by some 55 per cent. The additional cost per vessel operating in Australian waters is $288,000, which far offsets the $217,000 per vessel gained from the last round of industrial negotiations. The shipping fuel costs are now 43 per cent higher than our nearest competitor and are nearly 70 per cent higher than world best practice. How can we become internationally competitive with those costs?

We can also look at the additional costs of labour in Australia—which is ours alone—through payroll tax, the superannuation guarantee levy and the fringe benefits tax. They are greater than any of our competitors. These are the things that we must address if we are to bring Australia back to a competitive edge—not cabotage, the ownership issue or industrial awards. This factor is torpedoing our shipping lines at the moment. How they can survive in the light of this is a major problem.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Family Payment Scheme

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I would like to draw to the attention of honourable members an anomaly in the family payment scheme, an anomaly that is sexist and highly discriminatory. I have a case of a constituent who is being discriminated against because of his sex. He is the father of a three-year-old and he has custody of his child. He is therefore eligible for a sole parent benefit. But the Department of Social Security will not pay the benefit to him. Why? Because under section 831(2) of the act, the payment must go to the female in any relationship, even though in this case the female is clearly not the custodial parent. The money has to be paid to the woman with whom he is living—he has recently formed a relationship—even though the child is clearly being looked after by the father and the female in this relationship has no children of her own. Still, the family payment is being given to the female and not the father.

PARA.TAB: Clearly the government is pursuing a narrow-minded, sexist policy, one that is clearly discriminating against men. If the government is serious about fairness, about consistency and about recognising the role that fathers play in parenting, then it must remove this highly discriminatory and sexist slant from the Social Security Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. The reforms to social security announced in the white paper are a major overhaul of the social security system. The central objective of these changes is to achieve a situation where, irrespective of unemployed people's circumstances—whether they are single, members of a couple with or without children—unambiguously they benefit from increasing their work effort. That is the central objective of those changes.

PARA.TAB: The changes have been broadly welcomed across the board. Robert Fitzgerald, President of ACOSS, states:

ANSWER.PARA: Liberalisation of the income tests on unemployment benefits and the introduction of the parenting allowances were a tremendous boost to low income earners.

This is in the light of some of the things the opposition has been saying. This is what people who actually work with low income people have had to say. David Cappo, National Director of the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission, states:

The major reform of the social security system centres on the introduction of new income test arrangements which recognise the increasing participation of women in the labour market. These arrangements are overdue and will provide much needed incentives and greater flexibility for individuals and couples wishing to increase earnings through casual and part-time employment.
Bishop Michael Challen, Executive Director of the Brotherhood of St Laurence, states:
The Government has been bold . . . changes to unemployment allowances should encourage people to take up more part time and casual work . . . significant assistance to low income families.

It is a set of changes which has been broadly welcomed. The parenting allowance, in particular, is a major element in those changes. What it means is that, in many existing situations where there is a couple with dependent children and one member of that couple is offered a low paid full-time job, that family can often end up worse off in financial terms by taking up that opportunity. This change changes that situation fundamentally. It also means that low income families have a more realistic choice as to whether they want one of the couple to stay home and engage in full-time parenting activities. It does that.

PARA.TAB: But this is contrary to the suggestions of some journalists, including Glenn Milne, in today's Financial Review. He asserts that the economic and social effect of the parenting allowance and income splitting are the same. That, of course, is an utter absurdity. There is a range of important differences both in the overall philosophy and the effect of our parenting allowance and the income splitting changes favoured by the opposition. Glenn Milne only referred to one aspect; that is, the parenting allowance goes directly to the carer whereas income splitting benefits the primary taxpayer. But that is just one, and not really the most significant, of the changes.

There are two other massive differences conceptually in introducing a parenting allowance, which is up to $132 a week, and which will benefit 118,000 low income families on average to the tune of $59 a week. It is a major redistributive measure as well as anything else, as well as helping to overcome these work force disincentives. Where it contrasts with income splitting is that income splitting is fundamentally regressive. Greater benefits go to people on high incomes and people at the bottom end of the scale actually lose under income splitting. That is one huge difference. Our parenting allowance is a highly targeted payment which is directed towards low income families specifically. The other major difference is in the impact on incentives to participation.

In looking at this, we have to look at the totality of what we are doing here. As well as introducing the parenting allowance, we have decided to separately income test the two partners of a married couple. What that means is that, unlike the present situation where, say, we have a married couple where one of the partners does a day or two of part-time work and earns a bit of income, if the second partner is contemplating taking up a part-time work opportunity, they face a $25 free area. Once they have earned that first $25, they go straight into a 100 per cent withdrawal rate—a massive disincentive to taking up significant work effort.

PARA.TAB: Last Friday, I was in the electorate of the honourable member for Farrer to make it very clear that the government takes an interest in rural and regional communities and that we see the recovery as including all of regional Australia and as providing the mechanisms by which the leadership of regional groups—and I was at pains to commend the leadership qualities of the group leading the debates and changes in the Sunraysia—will have made available to it financial support to develop plans and strategies.

There is no doubt that when one looks at a regional area, as I had the opportunity of doing the other day—where the easily thrown about political notion is `If you're not bringing a big cheque, don't come'—one finds people who say, `Our problem is that farm sizes are too small, and we have gravitational irrigation when we should be into drip irrigation. We also have problems with the water table.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Too many taxes—fuel tax, petrol taxes, fringe benefits tax.
—I warn the honourable member for Maranoa.

—Obviously the focus of a community and the coalescence of view by a community on these things counts greatly, mightily and much more effectively than anything that could be delivered off any budget. But it is strategic investment by the government in these communities which matters most. I would have thought that the Leader of the National Party would have welcomed the government explaining these sorts of policies to communities like his and, therefore, not cavil at the program.

—Can the Minister for Transport inform the House of the government's decision in respect of the fast-tracking of Badgerys Creek airport? What will be the social and economic benefits of this decision for western Sydney and the Macarthur region as well as for the inner suburbs of Sydney?

—I thank the honourable member for Macarthur for his question and his particular interest in the question of a new airport for Sydney's west. I will be relatively brief. I can confirm that in the white paper we agreed to the accelerated development of a major runway at Badgerys Creek that is capable of handling large aircraft both taking off and landing.

PARA.TAB: It is now proposed that that 2,900 metre runway be commissioned by 1998-99. It is a real runway, not a pretend runway. We see it as an essential catalyst for the future private sector investment in the airport, the associated airport services and the terminal facilities that are necessary for the establishment of regular public transport operations there. In addition to the airport, we have also set up a task force to make sure that the necessary planning is undertaken for an early expressway link and the reservation of a rail corridor so as to meet future demand for transport between Badgerys Creek and Sydney airport.

The major beneficiaries of these developments are the people of western Sydney, who have direct access to the airport facilities years earlier than had been originally proposed. There will be a significant direct and indirect employment opportunity available in western Sydney and the Macarthur region flowing out of these works. The establishment of a major airport is also likely to attract other industries to the region, again with consequent employment opportunities for western Sydney.

In conclusion, the establishment of this airport has also been strongly supported by residents living in Sydney's inner suburbs. Those residents have long called for the acceleration of the second Sydney airport in the knowledge that its development will protect them from the further erosion of the existing night curfew at Kingsford Smith. Our decision accordingly results in a win-win situation for the people of inner Sydney and the western regions of Sydney.

PETITION.TITLE: Anzac Day
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

PETITION.PARA: The Anzacs at the Gallipoli landing on 25 April 1915 were instrumental in forging a new identity for Australia. That landing was a lifetime ago but the deeds of those Anzacs of 1915-18 still speak a message of selfless service and sacrifice that will last forever.

Anzac Day is a day to remember those who left their homes with a strong desire to return but did not, as well as those who did return, but in so doing carried for the remainder of their lives the scars of these experiences.

It is a day to contemplate the spirit that moves men and women to serve, to suffer discomforts, dangers and fears and to risk their lives in defence of their country and in the pursuit of peace, justice and freedom.

On Anzac Day, we salute not only the spirit of the Anzacs but, in paying tribute to them, we take the opportunity to dedicate ourselves to striving for our country as they did and to upholding their finest qualities of courage, commitment, endurance and mateship.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore pray that the House urge the Government to declare Anzac day as Australia's National Day of Commemoration and that it be held on 25 April in each year, and on no other day.
