TALK.START.PARA: —Last Friday afternoon, 6 May, I attended a most moving ceremony in the Bundaberg botanical gardens. Some 500 Bundaberg residents and visitors, including 150 who flew from the Solomon Islands, attended a weekend of activities which celebrated the centenary of a locally founded church and participated in an unsolicited act of reconciliation with Australian people.The venue was the verandahs and grounds of one of Australia's great colonial buildings, Fairymead House. This huge 64-square house, built along the lines of a classic Indian bungalow, forms a unique part of Australia's architectural heritage and has a unique place in the lives of many associated with the Queensland sugar industry. The Fairymead plantation, which was founded in 1880 by the Young brothers, Ernest, Horace and Henry, owes its name to an early visitor who, looking out on the fields in the rising mist, said that it looked like a veritable `fairy mead'.

PARA.TAB: Fairymead House stood in the cane fields, just north of Bundaberg, adjoining Fairymead mill. In 1890 it became the home of the Young family, the members of whom have made a significant contribution to the sugar industry, first, in their own right, later, as the Fairymead sugar company and, still later, as the Bundaberg Sugar Co., of which Fairymead was an early and major component. In 1988 the house was donated to the city of Bundaberg, along with a sizeable donation of $40,000, and moved to the botanical gardens where it stands in juxtaposition across the lakes from the equally famous Hinkler house.

Why, you might ask, do I give this historic background? It is because this house and the Young family were inextricably linked with the event which these Solomon Islanders and Australians of South Sea Islander background were celebrating. It was the 100th anniversary of the South Sea Evangelical Church. This group ranks with its Catholic and Anglican brethren as one of the most significant Christian groups in the Solomon Islands. Ernest, Horace and Henry Young had a sister, Florence, who loved these Melanesian workers and commenced Bible lessons for them in 1882. From these humble beginnings followed, in the 1930s, a simple timber church and church hall which, I might add, have been donated by the Bundaberg Sugar Co. to the South Sea Evangelical Church in recognition of the family and to celebrate the centenary.

Returning to 1884, the mission commenced in earnest, and Peter Ambuosa returned to Melanesia with the object of bringing his people to Christianity. That, in essence, was the reason for the celebration. Because of the repatriation of South Sea Islanders in 1906, many took their acquired Christian teachings with them. In fact, 18 per cent of the Solomon Islanders see Bundaberg as the genesis of their faith. As I sat looking out at these 500 local citizens and visitors, I must admit that I was filled with emotion: how could these people who, as a race, had been treated so wretchedly by generations of their Anglo-Australian masters return so openly and happily to celebrate their heritage?

After an address of welcome by the Bundaberg Mayor, Alderman Nita Cunningham, Bobi Kusilifu gave an unbiased, if not generous, appraisal of the South Sea Islander heritage in Australia. He was followed by the guest of honour, the Hon. Michael Maeliau, Minister for Home Affairs in the Solomon Islands government. His speech was truly memorable. Putting behind him the inhumanity, beatings and ill-treatment, he offered a pledge of forgiveness and reconciliation. He said that the Solomon Islanders' tradition is that, when forgiveness is offered, it is absolute and unequivocal on their part. Without either judging or reflecting on the efforts between white and indigenous Australians for reconciliation, I could not help but observe how abundant was the goodwill from these people who had made such a significant contribution to Australia's early economy and received so little in return.

Such a generous act of faith demands an examination of our own collective conscience on how Australia has treated its citizens of South Sea Island extraction. I refer the House to the motion moved by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) on 30 September 1993. It states:
That this House acts urgently to respond to the recommendations in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission's report entitled The call for recognition to ensure:
(1)an end to discrimination against the descendants of South Sea Islanders;
(2)acceptance of programs to provide these persons with equal opportunities in building, health education and legal representation;
(3)the retention of their culture, arts and heritage; and
(4)that descendants of South Sea Islanders remain proud Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: At the time, he lamented that the report of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission of 15 December 1992, then nine months on, had not been acted upon in relation to the South Sea Islanders. Now, another 7 1/2 months further on, nothing has changed.

PARA.TAB: While, as a nation, with faltering degrees of enthusiasm, purpose and effectiveness, we have sought to address the injustices of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, little has been done for those of South Sea Island extraction. Against Australia's 230,000 Aborigines and 27,000 Torres Strait Islanders, there are approximately 20,000 South Sea Islanders who rely on conventional avenues of support to advance themselves individually and collectively. There is no $1.3 billion ATSIC funding for them to draw on.

We might reflect on the appalling social injustices that were perpetrated on these people not only before but also beyond the physical aspects of the turn of the century; we might reflect on their forced repatriation when many of them, having worked their hearts out and built lives in Australia, were returned to their home countries to become outcasts all over again; and we might reflect on the most deliberate lack of educational facilities. This discrimination did not end until 1932-33 and shamed the then Queensland government to open special schools for Melanesian children initially around Mackay. It was not until the 1960s that a significant number of these children enjoyed secondary education, to say nothing of the refinements of such things as remedial teaching.

We might reflect on the mainstream churches that, after the repatriation of the South Sea Islanders to the South Pacific Islands, excluded those remaining from their mainstream congregations. We might reflect on those islanders, even Australian born, who were discouraged from working in the sugar industry. This was their entitlement as Australian born citizens. In fact, the Amalgamated Workers Association, later the AWU, denied them membership.

If we, the current generation, are fair dinkum, we might look at some specific catch-up mechanisms. These are not people with a handout mentality. They are proud and gentle people who have made a significant contribution to this country. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will recall that, when the honourable member for Dawson made his speech, he outlined those who had lost their lives fighting for this country in Vietnam. He outlined significant contributions by people such as the author, and Mackay citizen, Noel Fatnowna, Mal Meninga in sport and, I might add to that, Faith Bandler.

As a first step to correct these injustices and to respond to the act of reconciliation which I witnessed on Friday from these Solomon Islander people, we might select a small number of well focused catch-up programs in the fields of health, education and housing. Between 1863 and 1906, 62,000 people from 80 Melanesian islands became part of the wider Australian community. No group of immigrants, if we can call them that given the way they were recruited, were so badly treated. Nevertheless, a significant group of them chose, from different sides of the Coral Sea, to seek a new and unqualified relationship with Australia as it is today. The gesture calls for reciprocity.

In a weekend of functions, memorial services, cultural gatherings, et cetera, the leader of the group, the Hon. Michael Maeliau, extended gifts of war clubs, spears and war boats as symbols of aggression never to be used again, and certainly not against Australia or Australians. Amongst these, a symbolic club, which the minister asked to be presented to the Australian parliament, was given to me. I extend this symbolic club to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, on behalf of the Hon. Michael Maeliau, Minister for Home Affairs in the Solomon Islands government, and ask that you hand it to the Speaker.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! I thank the honourable member for Hinkler for arranging this and the manner in which he has presented it. I am pleased that it is an indication of a weapon not to be used for any further aggression.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Swan Mr W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in response to the shameful comments by the conservative parties last week concerning veterans entitlements. On the ABC and in local newspapers in Queensland honourable members opposite tried to scare our war veterans by telling them that the government is preparing to cut their benefits. This tactic was deplorable and was quickly squashed by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca). When asked about it in this House, the minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . under this government the principle will always remain that the ex-service community is a unique and highly respected section of our society and deserves to be treated in a special way.
He went on to say:
All Australians owe veterans from all campaigns a huge debt of gratitude—a debt which will be very difficult to repay in the future.

He went on to say that conservative members were `scaring an older section of our community by making people think they are going to lose entitlements which they will not lose'. The day that these allegations were made in Queensland calls came into my electoral office from veterans concerned about the loss of their entitlement. These people were scared. Some of them had fought long and hard to get their disability recognised and compensated. One old veteran said that years ago he was made to feel like a criminal when interrogated by various boards and tribunals about his claim for TPI. Given the latest allegations, he and others like him were being told that they could lose the entitlements that they had fought so hard for over the years.

PARA.TAB: This is a feeling which I am personally familiar with in the sense that in the mid-1970s my father had his disability pension arbitrarily cut. It took years for it to be restored and finally increased to a TPI pension following numerous appeals to the appeal bodies. He died, however, knowing that finally his country had valued his war service but he never forgot the crass and harsh attack upon his benefits by the then Fraser government. It is in this context that veterans have received the latest scaremongering from the conservative parties. One particular veteran visited my office and spoke about the added stress and anxiety the report had caused him and his mates. As he spoke his voice was shaking and the perspiration was running down his face.

There are people out there in our community working hard to ensure that veterans are treated fairly and justly. People like Eric Kay, state President of the RSL in Queensland, and Ted Tremayne, President of the Clayfield Toombul sub-branch of the RSL, are constantly on call for their members. People such as Kev Dean, President of the Sandgate branch of the Incapacitated Servicemen and Women's Association, a tireless advocate of disabled veterans, are constantly doing the rounds speaking to the veterans community. People such as Roy Glanville and Pat Quinn of the Kedron-Wavell RSL, Gordon O'Sullivan of the Sandgate RSL, Syd Bradly and Mick Beeston, President and Secretary of the Geebung RSL, Jim Comerford and Bert Bunning of the Banyo RSL and George Catchpole and David Prince from the Nundah-Northgate RSL all know just how alarming such claims from the opposition can be and what personal distress they cause to the veterans themselves.

This sort of scare tactic headline grabbing makes their work so much harder and creates unnecessary anxiety and suffering to people who have already suffered enough. This is particularly the case when we consider the government's recent record, which is eminently fair to veterans, in particular; the increases in the rate of service pension from 22.7 per cent of average weekly earnings in 1983 to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings—the last time the pension rate was higher as a proportion of average weekly earnings was in March 1949; the legislation that has been passed to ensure that the TPI pension is paid for life; the indexation of fringe benefits income limits in line with consumer price index movements; the extension from 1 April 1993 of the full range of Commonwealth fringe benefits to all service pensioners and to all war widows in receipt of a social security pension; the introduction of the extreme disabled with adjustment benefit for severely disabled veterans; and a seniors health card which will be extended to all those veterans, spouses and carers who meet the age requirement and are eligible for service pension but whose assets exclude them from receiving the pension.

The comments from members of the opposition are also particularly regrettable when one considers the policy alternatives put forward by them in this House. Although they profess to have dropped Fightback, they constantly come into this House and call for cuts in public expenditure. In particular, the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), constantly calls for this country to adopt Asian levels of taxation. Adopting Asian levels of taxation in this country would result in cuts to the revenue of between $10 billion and $20 billion.

Adopting a taxation level similar to that of Indonesia would require cuts to the revenue of something like $12 billion in this country. When it is considered that in the last budget the government allocated in excess of $5 billion to veterans entitlements, the sorts of spending cuts called for by the opposition would involve cutting the full amount of money allocated to veterans in this country twice over. The opposition is bereft of any serious policy in this area and it ill becomes its members to come into this House and elsewhere to use those scare tactics, which have no foundation in fact or government policy.

I would also like to talk briefly about long-term unemployment. We all know that it is a huge problem in our community, threatening not only the people involved but our whole social fabric. If Australia does not invest in the job compact as proposed in the white paper we will pay more later, economically and socially. Acting on long-term unemployment is not just a question of social justice, important as that is. It is also a question of economic efficiency.

Instead of looking at the bleeps on the computer screens, the money markets would do far better to look at long-term unemployment and all of the social and economic arguments for implementing a job compact to rid us of that problem. Dealers in the money market so critical of the white paper should take the time to drop into the Smith Family on their way to the futures market so that they can find out about what is happening in the present.

There is little awareness by some economists and money market dealers of the full extent of the problem of long-term unemployment. They are unaware not only of the social cost but also of just how many of our resources, human and capital, are being wasted. The fact is that long-term unemployment corrupts our labour market and erodes our competitiveness. If some of the dealers in the money market were being economically rational, they would consider the case for intervention in terms of warding off unnecessary wage pressures and inflationary pressures flowing from the skills mismatch between available vacancies and the unemployed.

As Ross Gittins has written frequently in the Sydney Morning Herald, the problem is that there is too little consciousness on the part of economists and idealogues in the money market of the extent of the problem. What many of them are unaware of is not just the social cost but also the huge waste of resources, both human and capital. Economists must be mindful of the numbers of long-term unemployed and the economic costs.

The fact of the matter is that cutting back on long-term unemployment is very good news for the budget and very good news for the economy. Dr Bruce Chapman of the Australian National University has produced a set of hard-headed calculations setting out the potential benefits of attacking long-term unemployment. He has found that, if we can decrease the number of long-term unemployed so as to cut 0.5 per cent off the current unemployment rate, those put to work will provide $110 million in taxes for the government and the reduction in unemployment benefits in one year will be $327 million. So the overall attack on the budget deficit is about $440 million. In addition, those long-term unemployed put back to work would add almost $800 million in additional output to the economy.

Dr Chapman has gone further and said that if we were to cut 0.876 per cent off the existing unemployment rate there would be a net gain to the budget of $765 million. Reflecting further, he stated that if we gain impetus and succeeded in cutting the unemployment rate by 1.25 per cent the benefits to the budget would pass $1 billion, reaching almost $1.1 billion. The saving in unemployment benefits would be over $800 million and increased tax receipts would approach $300 million.

What I find depressing is that so many dry economists, dealers in the money markets and others take none of this into account. The only solutions they put forward are cuts to the social safety net and challenges to the strategies suggested in the white paper. What the markets have to understand is that the white paper expenditure is a cheap way out. What I cannot understand is why they do not take the long-term view. The sorts of policies they advocate will produce an underclass. When they talk about cuts to the safety net everybody in this House should understand that the emphasis should be on the word `safety'. If we want to live in a civilised community free from poverty and tensions that produced events such as the LA riots, we have to take the long-term view. A recent report from the Australian Institute of Criminology concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: Our fear as criminologists is that two to three decades of continued relegation of more than 300,000 Australians to long-term unemployment may put us at risk of crime figures close to those of the United States.

There is the compelling case in the short term and in the long term to do something substantial about long-term unemployment. The measures advocated in the white paper—the measures which provide real incentives to business, the measures which shake up the Commonwealth Employment Service, the radical changes to the social security system—combined are producing and will produce the most comprehensive attack on this problem ever seen in this country's history.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am prompted to participate in this grievance debate by comments made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) during question time. During question time the Prime Minister reflected on his visit to the Sunraysia region and on what he had seen in the Sunraysia region while in the company of my colleague the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Forrest). The Prime Minster reflected on his concern about the message that had come to him in the Sunraysia about the need for irrigation redevelopment and about the particular frustration that he found with the fixture of small farm size that needed some sort of intervention, he felt, in order to be exanded.

PARA.TAB: I welcome the Prime Minister's foray into a region that is very like my own. I welcome his recognition, for the first time in this House, of what horticulture can offer in terms of a turnaround both in employment opportunities and in export opportunities for Australia. I particularly welcome his recognition of the fact that there is a need to change irrigation practice in the Sunraysia and, indeed, in the Murray-Darling Basin Commission area because that is much of what I have been saying during the 11 years or so that I have represented the seat of Wakefield in this parliament.

It is particularly pertinent that the Prime Minister should come into the House today, in May 1994, making a plea for the sorts of changes he felt were important after his visit to the Sunraysia. I suspect that my state right now faces the real threat of drought conditions. I am not a scaremonger, and I concede that it may well rain within the next month and the threat of a drought may be averted, but we certainly have experienced, as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan), who is at the table, would be aware, the driest March in 124 years and a real failure of rain since November last year. This means that the reservoirs that are part of Adelaide's catchment area for domestic water are now running desperately dry and are being topped up and maintained only by constant intervention of water from the Murray, charged of course from the Murray-Darling Basin.

It is also not without coincidence that my observations and the Prime Minister's remarks occur in 1994, which is the centenary of irrigation development in the Riverland area. I thought, in view of the remarks made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan), and in view of his reflection on the white paper, it was worth the House considering that in 1894, 100 years ago, the government of the day decided to intervene in the economy, as the government of today has decided to intervene, and provide an opportunity for those who had been unemployed and who had been caught up in the bitter recession that had preceded 1894 to set up irrigation settlements along the river.

It is interesting to note that those irrigation settlements, established at Waikerie, Moorook, New Residence and Lyrup, had varying success. In their early days, the only opportunity new settlers had to access any one of these settlements and the only way provisions could be got into the settlements was principally by way of paddle-steamer down a river whose flows were unpredictable. Sometimes the area was accessible; sometimes it was not. As a result of this uncertain accessibility we had the settlements of the river serviced irregularly, facing all sorts of medical deprivation, facing sometimes food deprivation. The fact that the river's flow was so unpredictable meant that the irrigation settlements they established sometimes ran short of water because the pumping location was not low enough to pick up what was a diminishing water flow.

As you will appreciate, Mr Deputy Speaker, these were communities in which frustration was inherent. It is interesting to note that these communities were originally set up as communal settlements. Every member of the community was expected to make a contribution into a common pool and to withdraw resources from that pool as they were required. While the intention in these settlements was no doubt honourable, they failed for a very human reason. In many instances, the family men decided that this was to their advantage because they were quite rightly able to draw more from the pool to support their families. But the bachelors in the communities became frustrated because they saw themselves as making every bit as energetic a contribution to the pool but were unable to withdraw the same amount from it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The community based pubs survived, though.

—The parliamentary secretary has made an interesting intervention about the concept of cooperative public houses, which I freely concede did subsequently survive. Even today, cooperative irrigation—that is, water distribution—has also been very successful. But the concept of a communal settlement failed. It needs to be recognised that this was a very important exercise in social engineering that failed. It was originally set up by the government as a role model for government intervention, relieving the desperate need of the unemployed in 1894.

PARA.TAB: I do not want my remarks to be construed as some sort of criticism of the government. In fact, I am the first to concede that much of what the government has done in maintaining the existing Murray-Darling Basin has been commendable. In my own electorate, between the communities of Woolpunda and Waikerie, the government has spent about $25 million on salt interception schemes to keep these riverland settlements alive and well and to ensure that the quality of water in the river is maintained. That $25 million picks up what is a natural saline inflow—not a drainage saline inflow—resulting from the area having once been a vast inland sea. The consequent salt interception scheme, which involves 49 bores along both sides of the river, intervening in water that is two-thirds as salty as seawater, has meant that the salinity at Morgan, at the point at which the river ceases its westward journey and turns south to the sea, will be reduced by eight per cent. That is commendable.

I concede that government intervention from both sides of the House, but currently from the Keating government, has been useful in maintaining water quality. However, I qualify that comment by referring to the experience of the people of 1894 when government intervention effectively failed because it imposed on them a nanny state. The government wanted to assume responsibility for everything and they desperately wanted responsibility, particularly for the direction that they were choosing to take.

In light of May 1994 and the white paper, I think it is useful for the government to consider the opportunity that horticulture currently offers in terms of job creation. My criticism of the white paper is that there is too much emphasis on training and too little emphasis on job creation. The government has clearly recognised, by its decision in the white paper to inject $850,000 into the Sunraysia community, that putting money into horticultural areas will generate opportunities for horticultural advancement and export income.

My plea in this grievance debate is that the $850,000 ought not be made available in lieu of the commitment the government already had to River Murray salinity control; that is, I do not want it to be part of the capital works funding that I have already enjoyed in my electorate and that has to happen in the Sunraysia, regardless of the white paper. Rather than using the instrumentality of the white paper as some form of intervention in the life of the community, I call on the government to recognise that those communities are already alive and well. In the case of the dried vine fruit industry, the dried tree fruit industry and the wine grape industry, those growers are doing well. The opportunity exists for the government to build on its white paper in tomorrow night's budget.

The government should offer the one industry which is most burdened in the Sunraysia, in my own area and in the Riverina-Darling—that is, the citrus industry—an opportunity for some sort of tax break. Currently, if citrus processors use 25 per cent of Australian juice, they get a sales tax concession on the juice that they produce. But under GATT that 25 per cent arrangement would have to disappear. I think it would be appropriate for the government to consider supporting these horticultural areas, not only by this injection of Sunraysia funds but also by treating the citrus industry as the dairy industry is treated and treating 100 per cent juice just as pure milk is treated. Therefore, pure juice should be treated as sales tax exempt. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay The Hon E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology)

TALK.START.PARA: —Science and technology are vital to Australia's future. In increasingly highly competitive and contested markets, technological innovation is fundamental for firm survival. Innovation is a necessary part of investment and economic growth. In building on Australia's capabilities in science and technology, there must be a realistic assessment of our strengths and weaknesses.

PARA.TAB: Australia's previously inward looking industry policies, adopted over many years of coalition rule and extended during the Fraser era, damaged the technological fabric of our manufacturing base. Further, the increased importance of manufactured goods in international trade and the need to further process Australia's mineral and agricultural products have demanded renewed technological effort.

The opposition—the Liberal and National parties—is completely unsympathetic to these changes and the challenges facing the nation. Honourable members will recall how the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) came under the spell of his svengali, the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), who was the self-proclaimed political mastermind of that 500-page suicide note known as Fightback. Who is the honourable member for Goldstein? David O'Reilly, writing in the Bulletin of 3 December 1991, described him as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Kemp, 49, is Hewson's shadow minister for education, one of the little-known frontbenchers who would evolve into household names only if the coalition won the 1993 election. Quietly spoken, with a tailored beard and piercing blue eyes, he played a vital role in helping to construct the GST package. After Hewson himself, Kemp became the mastermind of the most adventurous piece of political and economic policy making by an opposition.

Furthermore, an article in the Australian of 18 March 1992 was headed `Kemp wants fair go for rich Australians'. An article in the Age of 8 March 1990, written by Tim Colebatch, quotes the honourable member for Goldstein as saying:

"It was the Fraser government that really stood at the turning point of Australian history . . . It was during those years that the agenda which is still being written and carried out was first initiated."
That is in stark contrast to an article by Michael Warby, a member of the Federal Council of the Liberal Party, in the Quadrant magazine of May 1994. It stated:
The Fraser Government presided over the period when high inflation, mass unemployment and plummeting national savings rates became entrenched, and growth in living standards stagnated.

That was not the end of it. In an article published in the Bulletin on 13 August 1991, under the heading `Education', the same David O'Reilly referred to the honourable member for Goldstein in these terms:

The operation of the market would gradually permeate education. Shadow minister David Kemp says by the end of the century the local school should have greater control over its own destiny, being essentially an independent "enterprise" where the principal, for example, would have the power to hire and fire staff and parents would have greater power as "consumers". Schools would be funded by their capacity to attract students.

In his own right, as shadow minister for education, the ideological prescription of the honourable member for Goldstein would have damaged the future of education in Australia. The coalition's education policy was condemned by the electorate at the last election. Perhaps the coalition considers the honourable member for Goldstein safely placed in the science portfolio where his electorally damaging excesses will have little impact. But I urge the Liberal Party to consider not just electoral expediency but also the national interest in the allocation of portfolios.

PARA.TAB: Many countries in our region would find it strange to have a shadow minister for science denigrating Australia's capabilities. Australians should not underestimate the damage his statements can make. It becomes more serious when the Leader of the Opposition receives his information through the ideological filter of the honourable member for Goldstein. The Leader of the Opposition, in his address on science and technology delivered on 27 April this year, informed his audience at Monash University of the following:

SPEECH.PARA: A recent study by UNESCO found that the science and technology effort of countries such as Singapore, South Korea and Taiwan now surpassed that of Australia.

A similar assertion is to be found in an article by the honourable member for Goldstein in the Australian of 26 February 1994. That statement is false. Australia spends more on R&D than either Singapore or Taiwan. As I informed the House on 25 November 1993 during the grievance debate:

In 1990, Australia's expenditure on research and development was $US4 billion. In the same year, Singapore's research and development expenditure was approximately $US320 million. Based on UNESCO data the expenditure on R&D by the ASEAN countries, in total, was less than $US1 billion, a quarter of the R&D expenditure of Australia.

Australia's scientific research effort is efficient and effective. A measure of Australian research effectiveness is the share of published work in scientific journals made up by Australian scientists. Australians contribute about 2.1 per cent of world scientific papers, more than double the combined total of South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore and Malaysia, whose scientists contribute about one per cent of scientific papers. These figures clearly demonstrate that Australian scientific research output far exceeds the combined total of those countries.

PARA.TAB: Instead of deriding Australia's research and development effort, the Leader of the Opposition should be promoting Australia as a regional powerhouse of research and development. If he took the time to talk to the state premiers, I am sure that they would tell him that Australia is one of the most competitive places in the world to undertake research and development.

The fact is that Australia is attracting the world's best research companies and their staff. Major international enterprises with significant investments in R&D in Australia include Digital, UNISYS, Oracle, Ericsson, IBM and Societe Internationale de Telecommunications Aeronautiques. Firms which have made recent decisions to establish R&D centres in Australia include Data General, Canon, Motorola, NCR, Siemens and Microsoft.

Digital has established a global development centre at Bond University to act as a focal point for Optus's operational support system, R&D and engineering expertise for global telecommunications. The centre employs 45 R&D engineers and involves an investment by Digital of $50 million to the year 2000. In March 1994, Digital announced it will invest an additional $50 million by the year 2000, and this will involve an additional 40 computer software engineering jobs. Exports are estimated at up to $700 million over 10 years.

I could mention the work that has been done by UNISYS, Motorola, Siemens and Microsoft. Microsoft established its regional headquarters in Australia in 1993. The regional headquarters is responsible for key corporation mandates in the area of systems education, product development, the provision of developer support for the Asia-Pacific and key R&D. Microsoft has committed $65 million to R&D and exports over the next four years.

The honourable member for Goldstein has continued the practice he established as education spokesperson of attempting to ingratiate himself with his constituency regardless of his and his party's policy position. In his media release of 4 May, he stated that the white paper `misrepresents funding for science agencies as an increase'. The honourable member for Goldstein knows that the government has done precisely what it stated it had done in the white paper—it has increased funding by $34 million per year over the next three years. The funding base is from the forward estimates published and available for all to read in the budget delivered last year in August.

While playing games with statements by the government, the opposition remains coy about its own intentions. The personal philosophy of the honourable member for Goldstein has been outlined in a speech entitled `Dismantling the juggernaut'. He advocates `liberalising the technology market' and pointedly refers only to education and basic research—not strategic research—as areas of public good that markets cannot adequately provide.

I appeal to the opposition. The time has come to throw away ideological blinkers and embrace a bipartisan approach to the nation's science and technology capability—a bipartisan approach based on recognising Australia's strengths, not denigrating them, and recognising that there has been an explosion of innovative activity in Australia's best firms. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last few weeks, thousands of women in my electorate have signed petitions seeking that the government increase funding for breast cancer treatment and research. I am sure that many women across the nation have also signed petitions. I understand that petitions will be presented to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) today to present to the House. Many thousands of signatures will appear on them.

PARA.TAB: In Australia today, 100,000 women have breast cancer disease and every year in the order of 2,500 women die of breast cancer disease. It is time that the government recognised its responsibility and initiated a national strategy for breast cancer treatment and research. It has neglected to address the matter in a systematic way. We have heard a lot of rhetoric about breast cancer over the last few years, but we have not seen much real action.

I find it difficult to understand how medical researchers and the medical profession can stand up today and criticise parliamentarians when we take this issue to the public and see that it is forwarded in a positive way. For too long parliamentarians have been accused of just getting up, spouting rhetoric and not taking any action. This time we have acted on this important national issue. The accusations from the media, the medical profession in some areas and cancer foundations have come in thick and fast.

It is very important that the government develops a strategy. The benefit of a national strategy is well supported by the success of the national heart program, which has achieved a drop in the mortality rate of heart disease. A similar approach must be put in place to tackle breast cancer. This issue simply has to move beyond politics, both in this place and within the medical fraternity. It is a killer disease that delivers sick women every day to death, and it affects many of the nation's families. The strategies that need to be put in place are numerous, but they include things such as new treatment and resources.

An expanded program will be designed to ensure early detection. We need an awareness and an education program to educate the women and men of this nation and the general practitioners. We need a network for the coordination and exchange of data. At the moment, it seems to be a little hit and miss. We need to increase the number of women with breast cancer admitted to clinical trials. I think at the moment about 250 women are involved in clinical trials. Dr Forbes would like to see that expanded to 3,000 women. At the moment, the funding is not there to allow this expanded clinical trials program to proceed. That should be part of the whole approach, part of the total strategy of addressing this issue of breast cancer treatment and research funding.

In that strategy we need to look at issues in detection and treatment, such as the difficulty for country women who cannot afford to leave their families and head to the city for weeks of protracted treatment in the case where they are found to have a malignancy. So many of these women have to opt for a total mastectomy, which means the total removal of the breast and surrounding tissues, instead of a partial treatment which would mean the retention in most cases of that woman's breast. I think it is a sad indictment of the way we have proceeded with the treatment programs and the detection programs that we do not offer to our country women opportunities to have the same kinds of treatment as women in the city areas.

The coalition at no time has advocated an increase in funding without a proper strategy to ensure that funding allocated does produce the very best results. I am sure that all of us would want to see that. But it is a great shame to this nation that the concern by many parliamentarians on both sides of this House has been hijacked by criticisms, as I said earlier, from many people across many interest groups. A joint statement put out recently by the Australian Medical Association and the Royal Australasian College of Physicians warned that it would be a tragedy if politicians dictated the research agenda for doctors and scientists. I did not think that the call for increased funding meant that politicians were going to dictate the way in which those funds were to be utilised within the area of breast cancer research.

They went further to warn that Australia's high standard of medical research would be threatened if medical research funding were not channelled through a peer review. Again, I do not think that there is any indication that decisions about how breast cancer research funding would be used would be dictated to by any of the parliamentarians supporting this issue in the House.

They went further to say, `We strongly support additional funding being made available for breast cancer research.' I am not quite sure what they mean by this. It would seem to me that both of these statements are in contradiction. But, they said, the best way to do this is to increase the total pool of funds available to the NHMRC for medical research purposes. I have no argument with this at all. We all know that in Australia today we set aside 1.4 per cent of our total health budget to medical research. That is a total disgrace in a developed nation like Australia. The international best practice is two per cent. We have seen the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) get up in this place and beat his chest and say that he is going to increase research funding up to two per cent, but then comes the bad news—not until the year 2000. It is not good enough that by the year 2000 we will lift our funding to the point where it is in other developed nations today. The Prime Minister must with some urgency address the need to lift medical research funding here today.

Laurie Wright from the Cancer Council warned that the minister could be setting a precedent for the government. He said she could be putting her foot on a fairly slippery slope by using political persuasion to get more research on a nominated disease—that if the government is seen to bend to pressure groups and certainly if there is a very powerful lobby headed by no less than the Prime Minister's wife, then we do not know what issue will be picked up by an equally powerful group. But that precedent was set some time ago. It is an unfortunate fact that when the government allocated $10.5 million in 1993 to the national AIDS program fund, the process of lobbying for medical research was well established. The precedent has been set. It is the government who has taken the lead on this agenda.

No-one can blame women and men in Australia for taking the initiative to lobby government over a disease that affects so many families and with a death rate reputed to be increasing at the rate of two per cent per annum. Senator Richardson, in answering a question put to him by Senator Kay Patterson on Commonwealth funding for research, made the point himself that funding for medical research is not distributed on the base of disease state. I am not quite sure what he means by that. The National Health and Medical Research Council, he went on to say, advises the government on the allocation of funding for health and medical research and proposals are assessed on the basis of scientific merit, not specific disease state. If that is the case, why have we had a budget directed to AIDS research that in the last several years has exceeded $10 million?

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the reports of the Committee of Privileges in connection with the matters referred to the committee by the House on 28 October and 17 November 1993, together with the minutes of proceedings.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The first report I present concerns the unauthorised disclosure and publication of details of a draft report and deliberations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. The articles in question appeared in the Australian of 21 October 1993 and in the Australian Financial Review of 21 and 25 October 1993. In addition, comments on a WIN evening news broadcast on 25 October were referred to the committee. Each matter concerned a then forthcoming report from the public accounts committee on the operations of the Australian Taxation Office.

PARA.TAB: The evidence received by my committee enabled it to find that the publication of the articles complained of in the Australian of 21 October, one of the articles in the Australian Financial Review of 25 October and the comments on the WIN news broadcasts of 25 October, each indicated a knowledge of discussions which had taken place at private meetings of a sectional committee of the public accounts committee. These proceedings have not been authorised for publication. My committee was not able to make a finding in respect of two of the other articles complained of.

The committee received evidence of the effect that the unauthorised disclosure of the information in question had on the work of the public accounts committee. My committee was impressed by the evidence of the chairman and vice-chairman of the joint committee who spoke of the traditions of the public accounts committee in terms of its bipartisanship and the confidentiality which characterised its proceedings.

The Standing Committee of Privileges was unable to ascertain the source of the disclosures in question. If a person or persons responsible for the disclosure or disclosures acted deliberately, he, she or they were guilty of a serious breach of the prohibitions on unauthorised disclosure. In light of its findings, the committee is, however, unable to make any recommendations on the particular matter referred to it. The committee took the opportunity presented by this reference to consider the procedures which are followed in respect of complaints about the unauthorised disclosure of committee material.

Since September 1990, successive Speakers have required committees from which there have been unauthorised disclosures to undertake some preliminary consideration of the matter before a decision is taken by the Speaker as to whether a prima facie case exists. These procedures have served the House well, although, unlike the position in the House of Commons, they have not been endorsed explicitly by the House itself. In our view, it would be desirable for the House to adopt such procedures formally, and we have included in our report a draft resolution which would achieve this. We commend this proposal for the consideration of members. We also recommend that steps be taken to provide briefings for media personnel at which such matters could be explained.

The second report concerns the service of a writ on the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca). The writ in question was served on behalf of a Mr A. Robinson and followed a letter the honourable member for Bowman had written to the then Minister for Arts and Administrative Services concerning government decisions on Comcar. Mr Robinson took objection to comments made about him in the letter and caused a writ to be prepared and served on the honourable member for Bowman seeking damages for libel.

The committee has examined the relevant law on this matter and has received written and oral evidence and submissions from the honourable member and from Mr Robinson. The committee accepts that, in writing to the minister as he did, the honourable member for Bowman was making representations on behalf of constituents and others in circumstances that would be familiar to all members. It accepts that, as a result of Mr Robinson's action in causing a writ to be issued and served on him, the honourable member felt constrained in making further representations on behalf of his constituents in relation to decisions about Comcar.

The law is such that letters concerning constituency and related matters from members to ministers do not form part of proceedings in parliament. They are thus not protected by parliamentary privilege. Nevertheless, each House has the power to deal with offences which, while not breaching any particular right or immunity, do amount to improper interference with the free performance by a member of his or her duties as a member. The committee has considered this aspect in respect of this reference. We have been very conscious of the situation in which the honourable member for Bowman has found himself. We appreciate the constraint under which he has found himself after the writ was served on him.

The committee has concluded, however, that there is no evidence to establish that Mr Robinson had intended to interfere improperly with the free performance by the honourable member for Bowman of his duties as a member. It has found that, having regard to all the circumstances of the case, a finding of contempt should not be made in respect of Mr Robinson's action in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—In speaking to the reports of the Standing Committee of Privileges, can I first deal with the public accounts matter. Whilst not offering a dissenting report in relation to the matter, I think it is fair to say that the roles of committees have changed over time. I think the worst thing that can happen to a committee is that its recommendations be ignored, its report pigeonholed and no further action taken. I think the parliament has to understand, now that the House has adopted—very much at the urging of the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay)—a more vigorous committee system in line with the Senate, that very often a committee's role is just beginning rather than finishing when it brings down its recommendations. I agree with the Chairman of the Standing Committee of Privileges, the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford), that this presents a real difficulty for committees, given the current standing orders. As a chairman of a joint select committee, I must say that I think we need to work out the thin red line, if you like, between preserving the interests of the House and informing the public, which we have an overwhelming right to do.

PARA.TAB: But the more important report is the one concerning the issuing of a writ against the honourable member for Bowman. I am not issuing a dissenting report, but I want to say frankly to all honourable members that it is a very sad day when, having written a rather fulsome and frank letter to a minister which the committee has conceded is a legitimate communication between a member of the House and a minister, the subsequent publication of that letter has led to the issuing of a writ on a member and the privileges committee has been unable to find a breach of privilege.

This really goes in this modern era to the heart of the role of a member of parliament. It was all right at Federation when there were no offices and when people would come here for six months at a time and not be overly concerned about written forms of communications with ministers because, frankly, with seven portfolio ministers, business could be done in person anyway. But technology has moved on. People's demands have moved on. We have all now been beneficiaries of that revolution of actually having electorate offices amidst the people whom we seek to serve. We have all been part of that revolution that has given us staff in those electorate offices amongst the people whom we seek to serve.

Since my time, we have actually got fax machines. We have dispensed with pigeons and turbocharged pigeons; we have letters, we have faxes and, in fact, we can E-mail communications to ministers. But I regret to say, and I am sure my honourable and learned friend the chairman of the privileges committee would concede, that privileges have not caught up with that fact. I would assert on behalf of all members of this House that I ought to be able to frankly and freely state my mind to ministers of the Crown on behalf of my constituents unencumbered by the threat of a writ or a defamation suit.

I am sure the honourable member for Bowman, who was perhaps even more concerned about what was happening to Comcar than I was, felt that way when he first wrote that letter to the then Minister for Arts and Administrative Services. I do not argue before my peers that publication of that letter should be privileged—that is, that the publication in the Canberra Times should be privileged—but I do argue very strongly about the rights of members of this House to communicate to ministers in a very up-front way because I regret that these days, and perhaps it was ever thus, members sometimes need to do so to attract the attention of ministers and, if not their attention, the attention of their staff.

Having said that, I am very conscious that members of this House, and certainly members of the privileges committee, are very concerned that the rights and prerequisites of members should not overwhelm and overpower ordinary citizens. I think that is very perceptive because I think that is a function of the age in which we live. I would be one who would support that.

I find it very difficult to accept the argument that Mr Robinson, a senior public servant acting in charge of Comcare, who had served in a ministerial office, was somehow ignorant of the forms of the House and the force of privilege. This was no ordinary citizen of the Commonwealth; this was no ordinary citizen of the boondocks; this was no lowly clerk in a remote Department of Social Security or CES office; this was a powerful Canberra based bureaucrat.

In addition, Mr Robinson had had political experience with no less than a cabinet minister. Therefore, I do not say that he should have no rights before this House but that we ought to be cognisant of his background. We should not assume him to be innocent when he is fully knowledgeable. If anything, that is where I take exception to my colleagues.

But I am heartened by the Committee of Privileges. Mr Deputy Speaker, I suggest that you should be, as all other members of the House should be. We need to bring privileges up to the modern day. There ought to be no more cases like this one. When as members of parliament we write to the executive and ministers of the Crown, it ought to attract privilege. When we fax communications to ministers of the Crown, it ought to attract privilege. When we EPN through our electorate offices via the network, it ought to attract privilege.

I am heartened by the fact that my colleague the honourable member for Port Adelaide and the privileges committee are going to examine this very issue. I believe that after they have examined it carefully and in detail they will agree with me that no member of this parliament should be intimidated by standing up in a very frank and fulsome way to the highest or the lowest in his or her electorate. We have an unfettered right to represent our members to ministers and to be unencumbered by threats, pressure or any consequence other than wishing to fight and stand up for those constituents. Whilst I support the Committee of Privileges report, I do so in the knowledge that things must and will change for the future so that no other member will be placed in the same position as the honourable member for Bowman.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs commenced this inquiry in September 1993 following a request from the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) on 31 August 1993. The Attorney expressed a hope that the committee could report by the end of 1993. This was because the President of the Law Reform Commission—at the time Justice Elizabeth Evatt—was due to complete her appointment in November 1993.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, it was not possible to complete the inquiry in so short a time. The terms of reference require the committee to consider not only the role and function of the Law Reform Commission but also its relationships with a number of other bodies with an interest in and impact on law reform. The gathering of this evidence has taken a good deal of time and effort. The committee expects to bring down its report on 30 May 1994.

Having regard to the difference in time between the Attorney-General's requested tabling date and the likely tabling date, and to ensure there is no delay in any matters to which the Attorney-General may wish to give his attention, the committee considers it desirable to report to the House on its progress with the inquiry.

This is the first comprehensive parliamentary review of the Law Reform Commission since it commenced operations almost 20 years ago. The committee's terms of reference require it to examine the optimum role and functions of the commission as a separate and permanent law reform agency, amongst other things. In considering this, the committee is to examine the membership structure of the commission.

The Law Reform Commission was established by statute in 1973. The commission commenced operations in 1975 under the chairmanship of Justice Michael Kirby. Justice Kirby was chairman for almost 10 years. In the 10 ten years there have been three chairmen—now called presidents—Justice Murray Wilcox, Hon. Xavier Connor and Justice Elizabeth Evatt. The deputy president, Ms Sue Tongue, is currently acting as president.

During the inquiry, the committee has given much attention to the structure of the commission, but does not wish to pre-empt the findings of the report which will be tabled in a few weeks. The following observations will come as no surprise to those who have been following the evidence to the inquiry.

The committee is of the view that the Law Reform Commission has performed a valuable function during the past 19 years. It should continue to act as the central body considering law and possible law reforms as requested by the Attorney-General.

The basic structure of the commission as set out in the Law Reform Commission Act 1973 has been an appropriate foundation for the commission's role. The committee sees no need for any major departure from past practices relating to the selection of the commission's office holders.

This is not to say that the act cannot be improved in order to promote more modern management practices and to reflect the changes in public administration that have occurred during the past 20 years. The committee will be addressing these and other issues in its report.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The opposition agrees with the statement read by the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham). We join with him in seeking the House's understanding of our reasons for a delayed response to this report. Given the scope of the terms of reference and the time the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) proposed, with hindsight we realise that it was too large a task to review the activities of the Law Reform Commission in eight to 12 weeks. When one takes into account the scope of the submissions already received and considered by the committee, one realises that the Attorney-General had suggested to us an unrealistically short time.

PARA.TAB: That does not mean to say that we do not need to be diligent in the winding up of the inquiry. The committee has set a definite goal in that regard. The committee has set a goal of making sure that it is a high quality report rather than rushing to a conclusion and giving to the House and the government for their eventual consideration an unrealistically brief consideration of the recommendations. We have not been careless. The statement by the chairman accurately portrays the efforts that have been made, the scope of the report and the conclusion that we will reach in a set time.

PARA.TAB: The register proposed by the bill does not have any bearing whatsoever upon the employee arrangements or the employer arrangements within the industry. The bill requires a committee to establish a register for the names of stevedoring employees, and the amendment that is being proposed by the government will ensure that employers will not have to provide any employee information where, for example, time and wages records are being maintained. These proposals enable the requirements of the convention to be satisfied without any additional obligation on employers.

For normal transactions, there is already a requirement for normal activities to keep those records. So the bill, in effect, proposes streamlining the stevedoring legislation and maintains the reform that has already been achieved. I find it very difficult to understand why the opposition has been able to work itself into such a frenzy about this aspect of the legislation.

I also mentioned in Thursday's debate the comparison of performance of ports. Again, those who criticise the waterfront seem to be obsessed with what happens inside the wharf gate and are totally unable to see that there is life beyond the waterfront gate. In fact, there are greater costs incurred beyond the gate in the journey back to the landside origin or landside destination of cargo. There is greater potential in that area for improvement in productivity. This obsession with what happens inside the gate diverts us from what we ought to be looking at these days: how do we get the users of the waterfront to better coordinate their activities to get a better level of efficiency in how they fit in with the services being provided on the waterfront?

Again, the comparisons are made between Australian ports and external ports. I will run through some figures to put this into proper perspective. Making international comparisons with Australian ports is extremely difficult. Almost always the comparisons are of unlikes; Australian ports are compared with Asian ports. In 1992-93, for instance, the total number of 20-foot equivalent units, TEUs, handled by all Australian ports—and over a dozen of them handle some number of containers at some time—was 1.8 million. That compares with the largest port in the world, Hong Kong, with which we are often compared. In calendar year 1993 Hong Kong handled 9.62 million TEUs. Singapore, which is the second largest port, handled 9.04 million TEUs. Comparisons between individual Australian ports and ports like Hong Kong, Singapore and Rotterdam—as I have said, they are comparisons of unlikes—serve no useful purpose and confuse the debate rather than enabling us to concentrate on the areas where there is room for improvement.

If we look at last year 1992-93—I should correct those figures I have just used—we see that the actual number of TEUs handled in Australia was 1.935 million. In the six months to the end of December across Australia, in Sydney, Melbourne, Fremantle and Adelaide, 928,211 TEUs were handled. That does not include—there will be some addition to that—TEUs handled by the ports of Newcastle, Port Kembla and the Tasmanian ports; in all, more than a dozen ports. But it enables the parliament to get some grasp of this fragmented task we have in Australia. In New South Wales, in 1992-93 there were 565,000 containers handled. To get some sort of comparison, we can say that in New South Wales twice as many containers were handled as in Queensland. Victoria handles three times as many containers as are handled in Queensland over the course of a year. I mention that again to concentrate upon this fragmentation of the Australian task. It is idiotic and irresponsible to argue that we should be trying to achieve or are expected to achieve within Australia the same handling rates as are achieved in the great ports of the world, such as Hong Kong, Singapore and Rotterdam.

The next important point to make is that the size of ships we handle in Australia is much smaller than those handled in the great ports I have mentioned. The numbers of cranes used on those great ports are much greater. They might be working with one or two cranes. The configuration of ships is different. There are obstructions. If we go down to the port at Botany and look at the size of some of those ships, we find that they are carrying 250 to 300 containers with gear and away hatch covers, with the configuration I have mentioned, the location of the masts and the cranes. It is like trying to compare the unloading of a utility with the unloading of an unobstructed semi-trailer; they are just `unlike comparisons'.

The other point is the gear used in Australia. The youngest crane in Australia is 20 years of age. That compares to the `you beaut' gear being introduced in the great ports of the world. Then we have the comparisons where we are told that the costs or port charges of some of the port facilities are greater in Australia. What is not said in that kind of comparison, from whatever source it comes, is that in many of the overseas ports the capital investment is provided by government; the cost is not borne by the port users. So either the capital investment is subsidised or, in other cases, the ports are not required to pay dividends, as is the case in all of the major ports in Australia. In effect, the major ports in Australia have now all become de facto taxing agencies.

If we look at the comparisons of those, we will see that the level of revenue being extracted from the ports really amounts to an industry policy; that the state governments, particularly New South Wales and Victoria, require their port authority to level a scale of charges to generate the dividend that they want from those ports. In effect, that amounts to an industry policy. In both of those cases, the governments ought to come clean and declare it to be an industry policy rather than having this de facto tax or industry levy masquerading as simply a port charge.

The charges of the Maritime Services Board of New South Wales have been falling. Port revenue per tonne dropped from $1.73 in 1986-87 to $1.33 in 1992-93. But the question I want to ask is: how much further could that revenue have dropped if the MSB were not required to pay a dividend? With Commonwealth government business enterprises, GBEs, the government's standard for dividends is around 50 per cent of operating profit. In 1992-93 the Maritime Services Board of New South Wales had to pay almost all of its operating profit to the state government. It made a profit of $91.8 million, $89.5 million of which had to be paid or handed on to the state government by way of dividend. So I think it is fairly clear that the use of the ports and port pricing policies by state governments is a major factor in the charges that are imposed on port users for containers.

Queensland separately has made the point that in that state, in the process of corporatising its ports, it will not be converting its ports into milch cows, as have New South Wales and Victoria. That, in effect, will give Queensland an advantage. If we look at the upgrading of the National Rail Corporation which is taking place, it is well likely to be the case a few years further down the track that, as the Rail Corporation improves its performance and linkages with Queensland ports, they will benefit to the cost of the ports of Sydney and Melbourne. We might argue that Sydney and Melbourne will maintain a number of containers. However, if they maintain the number of containers that they are handling, it is more likely that they will not get their share of the growth that is occurring and which is ahead of us.

There will be competition between the ports for cargoes that are mobile and can be transhipped between ports, such as by the north-south land bridge we are talking about from Brisbane south to Sydney and Sydney south to Melbourne. That will have an effect on how the ports perform and, hopefully, on the state governments, unless the Council of Australian Governments at its meetings reaches an agreement that port authorities should not be operated as milch cows; that the concentration upon efficiency, productivity and minimisation of costs to users will be the priority. If there is to be some arrangement between federal government and state government over revenues that may have to be forgone or altered, I hope the Council of Australian Governments will have that item on its agenda and will be looking at improving performance in that way.
A paper from the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics, which was used recently, states:

SPEECH.PARA: One of the major issues in the debate about the Port Authority charges is the appropriate balance between ship and cargo based charges.

But, on a cost per TEU basis, cargo based charges, which are the charges levied by port authorities on behalf of state governments, still represent about 60 per cent of port and related charges. So the debate goes on from the other side of the House and out in selected parts of the general community about stevedoring charges and waterside workers. Waterside workers and stevedoring companies have improved their productivity and performance. They are doing a much better job, even though their youngest crane is 20 years of age and even though the utilisation rates in some ports are quite low. But, given that improvement has taken place, it is to little avail if the reductions being made there are being offset by the levying of state based charges, what we call cargo based charges which, in effect, are the charges levied for wharfage. That is the major area which is involved.

PARA.TAB: Then we have the continuing comparisons of unlikes. I turn to page 63 of the Bureau of Industry Economics report which deals with the overview of the international performance indicators. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Given the large number of ports comprising the Australian waterfront and the diverse cargoes moving through them, the bureau opted, in consultation with waterfront service providers and users, to focus on a selection of key cargoes in the main ports that handle them.
