TALK.START.PARA: —It is always interesting to sit and listen to the comments made by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), who is quite respected around this place for his experience and views on these matters, particularly on matters pertaining to his former portfolio. I will take up a couple of points that the honourable member has raised in comparing like with like. The honourable member for Shortland was comparing gross throughputs between some of the major ports around the world and some of the ports around Australia. What we need to identify is the productivity of the ports. Accepting the fact that our ports are smaller, that we have fewer loading cranes and that we deal with smaller ships, a comparison must be made between the productive ability of those ports.

PARA.TAB: We had the opportunity just recently to visit the port of Botany and to speak with representatives of both the stevedoring companies that deal in the port of Botany. They indicated to us that their throughput was just under 20 TEUs. I accept the point that some of the major ports overseas that the honourable member for Shortland alluded to have a much higher throughput rate of TEUs, but the accepted world practice standard should be around 26. It is certainly not impossible to ask that we should be aiming for that target in Australia. I accept that we might not be able to achieve the 30 TEUs that is achieved in Auckland, or the higher amount achieved in some of the ports that the honourable member for Shortland alluded to, but we should be improving on 19.

If it is a fact that the state governments are impeding the more competitive operation of our ports, the Council of Australian Governments should be discussing it. We are talking about a major impact and the impediment to our exporters in this country, not only to manufacturing exporters but also to mining exporters and exporters of primary products. It is a terribly important aspect of Australian industry, a terribly important aspect of our primary industry, and one which this parliament must pay particular attention to.

The honourable member indicated that there was an amendment coming from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton), but my understanding is that reference in the legislation to the register is not eliminated, and that is the concern of industry. The industry is arguing that waterfront reform was supposedly a move from industry based agreements to enterprise based agreements. The stevedoring industry does not believe that this bill is going to effect that.

The Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 amends the Industrial Relations Act 1988 to abolish special provisions for the stevedoring industry, which have become redundant in the Industrial Relations Act. It also seeks to amend the stevedoring industry levy acts purportedly to reflect changes in the industry. The Minister for Industrial Relations claims that this is following an industry move towards enterprise agreements. But we are saying that we are enshrining some of the pre-reform principles that used to be involved on the waterfront, rather than moving towards enterprise agreements with this amending bill.

There were changes to the composition and function of the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee, which administers the industry levies, and to confine it to administering only the special levies. These special levies include the Stevedoring Industry Acts (Termination) Act, Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee Act, Stevedoring Industry Levy Act and the Stevedoring Industry Levy Collection Act. The amendment will also insert sunset clauses in each of the three remaining levy acts so that they are automatically repealed when the SIFC has discharged its remaining obligations.

The stevedoring employers oppose this bill. The stevedoring industries are opposing it because, contrary to the assurances of the minister in the House, the amendments to the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee Act would reintroduce an industry register. It will again raise the spectre of industry levies and it will threaten the reintroduction of the industry labour pooling arrangements. This is counter to the entire enterprise thrust of the reform process.

A statement issued by the Association of Employers of Waterside Labour indicates that the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 must be amended—that is, as it is before us—if it is not to be an instrument for reversing waterfront industry reform in Australia. The offending features of the bill are the plan to provide for maintenance of a register of stevedoring employees; the intention to allow the imposition of additional or increased stevedoring industry levies; and the plan to remove the right of stevedoring employers, through the registered organisation of employers, to nominate the members of the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee to represent the employers, which seems a little ironic. The minister, in his second reading speech on this bill, with regard to the provision of that register, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The provision for registers was also relevant in meeting Australia's obligation in relation to ILO convention 137. At the completion of the reform program, all parties agreed that the registration system incorporated in the General Agreement of 1977 would cease to apply. The bill removes the requirement that the committee maintain a register of waterside workers for these purposes and in relation to levy collection, although the committee will establish a register of names of stevedoring employees, consistent with the convention.
Again, we have been criticised by the government for highlighting this point of the government tying this country to international conventions and, in particular, this ILO convention.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to have a look at which countries are signatories to this ILO convention and which are not and which countries we trade with that are signatories and which are not. I will read into Hansard the signatories to this convention: Afghanistan, Costa Rica, Cuba, Egypt, Finland, Greece, Guyana, Iraq, Italy, Kenya, the Netherlands, Nicaragua, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Spain, Sweden, Tanzania and Uruguay. The countries that have not signed the International Labour Organisation convention 137 are the United Kingdom, the United States of America, Germany, Canada, Russia, the Ukraine, Japan, Singapore, Korea, Taiwan, South Africa, Nigeria, Brazil, Argentina and Chile.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his No. 1 lieutenant, the Minister for Industrial Relations, have been dressing themselves up as the white knights who are going to lead this country away from being tied to Britain, tugging our forelock to the British, and who want this country to be independent and individual and not commit itself; yet we are continually being reminded about our ties to these international conventions. This is only one convention that is relevant to this particular bill, but it is being used as one of the mainstream arguments for the maintenance of a register as far as this legislation is concerned.

The Prime Minister is overseeing the increasing and burgeoning national debt of this country in excess of $200 billion. He has this place completely—the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Dr Theophanous) should not shake his head—mortgaged to the world banks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you talk about government debt instead of misleading the parliament?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon) —Order! The parliamentary secretary will please refrain from interjecting.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has us tied up to that many international conventions that every time something comes up in this place we find this nation has been committed to another international convention without reference to this parliament—a parliament that is representative of the people of Australia. If the opposition in this parliament wants to have any say on these conventions, we have to come to this place and move a disallowance motion. Again, we have heard from all the speakers on the government side on this bill of the use of that international convention as an excuse and a reason why we must maintain that register, which is diametrically opposed to what the waterfront reform was all about.

PARA.TAB: A number of the government speakers have also indicated how good we are going on the waterfront. There is no argument that it has certainly improved out of sight. But even the recent OECD report on Australia's performance has indicated that Australia's performance on the waterfront is still only 60 per cent of the OECD average. The government all too often will run off and use statistics produced by the OECD, and the government will put its spin on them when it suits it. But when it does not suit the government the statistics are not correct, they are not relevant—we are comparing unlike with like.

The honourable member for Shortland asked a while ago how we can compare ourselves to major ports like Hong Kong. But on a productivity basis per man per hour we must be able to. The equation used by the OECD indicates that we are operating only at 60 per cent of the OECD average and that the throughput of our container terminals, on the stevedoring companies' admission, is around 19.8 or 20 TEUs. The OECD has indicated that to be world competitive we should have a throughput of about 26 TEUs.

The stevedoring employees are obviously opposing this bill. They are opposing this bill because it is contrary to the assurances of the minister in the House. The amendments to the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee Act would reintroduce the industry register. It will again raise the spectre of industry levies. It will threaten the reintroduction of industry labour pooling arrangements. This is counter to the entire enterprise thrust of the reform process.

There is obvious disagreement and continued tension on the waterfront between employer and employee groups. The Maritime Union of Australia continues to believe that waterfront employees should enjoy employment arrangements above and beyond the rest of the Australian work force. That is what this is really all about. Why should one select group in the community enjoy a more privileged position in the industrial relations policies of this nation than any other section of the community? Why should they be different from people who work in other industries? They should not, but again we are seeing the organ-grinders, the particular unions around this country, getting their payback after bankrolling the Labor Party back into government last year. The minister is the monkey dancing to the tune.

This amendment bill is quite clearly the result of successful pressure brought to bear by the Maritime Union of Australia on the federal government so as to operate a statutory regime which is contrary to the basic principles of waterfront reform, which has already been bought and paid for by the taxpayers of this nation for $400-odd million. The MUA maintains that stevedoring employees are entitled to a job for life, except where the MUA agrees otherwise.

This is the feature of the waterfront industry which the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority said ended with its final report in October 1992. But the attitude of the MUA, as clearly demonstrated by the recent stevedores dispute, is clearly unchanged. Notwithstanding all the money that has been spent to buy out the special privileges of the waterfront employees, the MUA still insists on the right of veto over compulsory retrenchments, even when the retrenchment is economically vital to the health of an enterprise or otherwise in the public interest.

By supporting this bill the federal government is helping the MUA turn back the clocks to the ugly days of excessive union power. Last week one of the speakers—it was probably the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis)—challenged members of the opposition to read the judge's statement from the Industrial Relations Commission over that industrial dispute which came about when Australian Stevedores attempted to reduce its work force by 55. It had nothing to do with the conditions that existed. The reason the judge in that case indicated that those people should be reinstated was that Australian Stevedores did not go through the correct procedure in dismissing those men. In my view this is a fairly hollow argument.

That adds a bit of strength to the concern being shown by employers right across Australia with that same element in the Industrial Relations Bill, which the minister put through the parliament before Christmas in 1993. The onus of proof of unfair dismissal is being put onto the employer rather than the employee. It is a complete turnaround to what has been accepted as the norm where the employee, or the aggrieved person, goes to the Industrial Relations Commission and says, `I have been unfairly dismissed.' It is the norm right throughout common law in Australia that the person who makes the application to the court should be able to prove that he or she has been unfairly dismissed. It is the exact reverse in the industrial relations legislation introduced last year and it was borne out in this case. The reason the judge could instruct Australian Stevedores to reinstate those 55 employees was that the procedure it followed in the dismissal was incorrect.

The government has not explained the reasons for the reintroduction of the register. The government has told everyone that it is necessary to meet ILO convention No. 137, which requires the creation of registers for industry pooling arrangements. The industry has indicated the reasons the register should not be there. The register of waterside workers was a feature of the former industry based employment arrangements, the very point the Minister for Industrial Relations was using to sell the Industrial Relations Bill last year—because of enterprise agreements, not industry agreements. To work in the industry the employee had to be on the register. A registered waterside worker who was idle on a shift was entitled to be paid if available for work.

Collection of industry levies, which funded this and other industry wide employment obligations, was connected with the use of registered waterside workers. Industries which do not adopt industry employment structures have no need for industry registers of employees. Such registers could have no function. Indeed, a register would be an unnecessary imposition on employers, a potential bar to entry by new employers and an invasion of the privacy of individual employees. There is no future need for a register in the stevedoring industry if it is to have enterprise employment structures rather than industry-wide employment structures.

Maintaining a register when its former purposes have disappeared is contrary to the public interest. Why then is maintenance of a register proposed in clause 20 of the bill? I do not believe the proposed amendment does away with that aspect. If there is no need for a register, there is no need for it to be mentioned anywhere in the bill.

Maintenance of a register of stevedoring employees is keenly supported by the MUA. The reason the MUA insists on the maintenance of the register is the role it wishes the register to play in helping to enforce the MUA's view that stevedoring employees, unlike other employees in the community, should never be liable to compulsory retrenchment.

No plausible explanation has been given by the federal government for allowing the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee the function of recommending new and increased levies. Given the conduct of the MUA during the Australian Stevedores dispute and its attitude with respect to the register, the irresistible conclusion is that the federal government is deliberately leaving the way open for the introduction of funding arrangements sought by the industry to underwrite the cost of port pools for surplus registered stevedoring employees.

Even assuming that this might not be the conscious policy of the federal government, it is the logical consequence of the government's actions and it will leave the government open to the inevitable pressures brought by the MUA to preserve the MUA's crown jewels: jobs for life for stevedoring employees. However, the government has denied the logical consequences of the creation of such a register, which would be a push for a return to pooled labour arrangements and, presumably, some form of general levy. The government is therefore chasing its own tail in the drive for reform.

There is no sense in the simple creation of a register. It proves nothing and it solves nothing. The Maritime Union of Australia has already flagged its intentions to return to pooled labour arrangements. It has openly refused to concede individual companies' rights to terminate redundant labour—that was seen recently—and therefore the union would almost certainly use the register to try to re-introduce pooled labour arrangements across the country.

The re-creation of the register is inconsistent with the stated purpose of the winding up of the SIFC. In fulfilment of the federal government's micro-economic reform policy in the waterfront to date, employers have contributed $255 million and the federal government—the taxpayers—has contributed $165 million. This money has been spent in funding the special redundancy and early retirement program recommended by the Inter-State Commission and adopted by the in-principle agreement designed to see 3,000 stevedoring employees leave the industry.

The employers' contribution is funded by way of a statutory industry levy. Of course, in the long run it is the Australian consumer and the exporter that bears the great bulk of this cost either through taxation or higher consumer prices. The federal government now appears to be cooperating in a reversal of policy on these matters.

By persisting in its present course, the government leaves the way open for the Maritime Union of Australia to press for industry based solutions in respect of surplus labour and the imposition of new levies to fund that surplus labour. This should alarm anybody concerned to see the apparent gains from micro-economic reform on the waterfront not squandered. Minister Brereton has misled the parliament on this issue. He told parliament on 23 March that any decision to reintroduce a register would not be made by him. He claimed that the Australian Stevedoring Finance Committee will be making the decision. TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill was proposed to achieve a number of purposes: firstly, to secure the stevedoring industry levy collection arrangements, incorporating the abolition of the general levy and continuation of the special levy with respect to the financing of the redundancies that the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) has referred to; secondly, to restructure the functions of the Australian Stevedoring Finance Committee; and, thirdly, to abolish a variety of obsolete arrangements with respect to industrial relations that are specific to that industry. In order to do this, there are amendments to various acts of parliament relating specifically to the stevedoring industry and also to the Industrial Relations Act itself.

PARA.TAB: We have seen a wide range of reform on the waterfront during the period that this government has been in office, particularly under the auspices of the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority which was established by the Labor government. Widespread reform has emerged from a reform program negotiated between the ACTU and the government to apply for a three-year period from 1989 to 1992.

A new award for the industry called the Stevedoring Industry Award was negotiated, and that was ratified by the Industrial Relations Commission in November 1991. That new award replaced roughly 17 awards that previously applied in the stevedoring industry. It brought multiskilling into the industry. A new classification of stevedoring employee replaced the previous award classification of waterside worker. As a result of these changes, a number of organisations, including my own former organisation, ceased to have a role in the waterfront industry.

As a result of the introduction of multiskilling, even though the Federated Clerks Union still represented a significant number of waterside workers—namely tally clerks and clerical workers—it became apparent that it would be against the interests of those workers for us to seek to separately represent them any further. That would have denied them access to the benefits of multiskilling, of which there are a number, and it would have denied them access to career paths that were set out in the structure of the new award. Therefore, our organisation withdrew from that area and negotiated arrangements to hand over the rights of representation to the Waterside Workers Federation, which is now part of the Maritime Union of Australia.

I cite that as an example of how cooperation with government, the various unions involved—there is now one union—and, at least to some extent employers, has achieved a great deal on Australia's waterfront over the past five or six years. I think this contrasts fairly starkly with the record of the previous coalition government in this area.

The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and other opposition speakers in this debate have claimed that this legislation will bring back pooled labour and that the recent shift to company labour will be reversed. As has been stated by previous speakers in the debate, that is not the case. There are quite explicit and straightforward reasons why the register will be maintained in a particular form as a result of this legislation. Clearly, that does not relate to any suggested reintroduction of pooled labour.

Under this government, the work force on the waterfront has been reduced by 57 per cent and productivity has increased by roughly 60 per cent. The ship turnaround time has more or less halved. Container handling rates are now on a par with the most efficient ports overseas. We now have a single award rather than a multiplicity of awards. The rates that are charged for stevedoring services are now 20 to 30 per cent lower than they were previously. Given the change that has occurred in productivity and the amount of labour involved, one might ask why that change has not been greater. I recommend that the honourable member for Lyne examine other parts of the waterfront industry to explore some of the issues he has dealt with, instead of pursuing the typical coalition approach of blaming the workers and the unions.

Unfortunately, very little was achieved by the previous coalition government in this area. What the Labor government has achieved has been with the cooperation of the union. Given how difficult it is for any union to accept loss of jobs for its members and to accept a reduction in work opportunities for the people it represents, great credit must be paid to the Maritime Union of Australia—and previously the Waterside Workers Federation—for the fact that it has contributed to this process in the way that it has.

These amendments are in part necessary because employers have not been quite as cooperative in a process that they and their representatives in here say is so important. In particular, they have been less than cooperative in paying the levies that are required to fund the redundancies from the waterfront work force. It is ironic to see representatives of the coalition standing up in the House today and last week attacking the level of cooperation from the union in this matter when the union and the work force have been remarkably cooperative. It is the companies that, in some instances, have dragged the chain.

The register is being maintained to ensure that Australia continues to comply with ILO convention 137 dealing with dock work. This convention was ratified by Australia in 1974 and requires that a register be maintained as a basis for permanent employment and also as a basis for dealing with a variety of other matters such as occupational health and safety, training and similar matters related to employment.

It is a debatable point whether Australia needs to maintain a register in order to comply with the convention. But, in my submission, the better view is that we should maintain the register in order to ensure that we do comply. We have heard a few sneering references from one or two speakers on the other side about the countries that have ratified this convention as compared with those countries that have not. We hear that the United States, the United Kingdom, Chile and Argentina are examples of countries that have not ratified. The tone of the voices opposite indicates that the countries that have ratified are mickey mouse nations of no great consequence internationally. Yet these include such great maritime nations as Sweden and Greece, which have histories with respect to the maritime industry that are out of all proportion to the size of their population and their economies. So I suggest that some of the sneers that have come from the other side with respect to the list of countries that have ratified this particular convention are misplaced.

The convention is not inconsistent with enterprise or company based employment. It is quite clear that the former role that the register played in the controlling of access to employment on the waterfront will not continue and will play a different role. What is surfacing here is the opposition's paranoia about international conventions, treaties and the like and, in particular, the use of the external affairs power, which comes under section 51(xxxv) of the Australian constitution.

Time and again in the past few years the argument has been put forward that Australia is losing sovereignty to gangs of faceless United Nations bureaucrats and that the parliament is losing sovereignty. The facts are these: in order for any convention or any treaty to which we become party to have any impact at all in Australia, legislation must be passed by this parliament. It has to be ratified first. The honourable member for Lyne is quite correct when he says that the process for the opposition challenging ratification requires moving for disallowance. But to have any practical effect in Australia, any convention has to be legislated and put into law by the government and the parliament.

We have some extraordinary misconceptions in the community. I have cited this example in this place previously. Max Walsh, a journalist, stated that, as a result of the new Industrial Relations Act depending upon ILO conventions, whenever those conventions change, the Australian legislation will automatically change. That is absolute nonsense. Any changes that occur to ILO conventions must first be ratified by countries that have already ratified the substantive convention. Then, if those countries choose to—and Australia may or may not choose to—they are put into the legislation by an amendment to the relevant legislation.

The real underlying issue in all of this is xenophobia. It is the old hoary chestnut of states rights. It is the Liberals and the National Party trying to preserve archaic and oppressive laws in some of the states that they control from time to time and trying to ensure that the national parliament is unable to legislate on national issues that have an importance way beyond the role they may play in one particular state.

The constitution contains an external affairs power precisely for this reason. As we internationalise, as more and more activities require international regulatory action, whether they involve environmental issues, Labor issues or economic issues, or combined efforts by many nations, it is logical to expect that the external affairs power will be invoked more by this parliament in order to give effect to those international actions.

We now have the extraordinary spectacle of the conservatives in Australian politics undermining the institution of the High Court, the rule of law—something that they supposedly stand for. We did not hear them undermining the High Court back in the 1950s when Sir Owen Dixon ruled supreme and we had the strict literalist interpretation of section 92 which meant that sensible, ordinary government regulation of a variety of activities was undermined or destroyed because of an extreme literal interpretation of that section of the constitution. We did not hear them complain then about the High Court.

We did not hear them complain in the 1970s about the Barwick High Court, when tax avoiders were given carte blanche to effectively completely avoid the taxation laws and ensure that there was one law for the rich and another for the poor. It was then optional to pay income tax. There were no complaints from the Liberals then about the High Court and no suggestion that the High Court was making legislation or in some way supervening the role of the parliament. Now that the High Court is taking a position that the Liberals do not like, it is a different story.

As with most issues, the opposition has a class position. This is particularly apparent with respect to this legislation. At the end of the day, the opposition's stance on this issue boils down to the fact that it does not like wharfies. The reason is that some of the great formative battles of the Labor movement have been fought and won by waterside workers. They have battled casual employment, favouritism, victimisation, enormous health and safety issues—back injuries, industrial deafness or, more recently, the implications of handling asbestos such as asbestos related diseases. We have had repressive legislation such as the infamous dog collar act in 1928 of the Bruce government, formed from predecessors of the Liberal Party. So ultimately this is about a class position by the conservative forces: they do not like waterside workers.

It is accepted that reform has been necessary and that the enthusiasm of the conservative forces contrasts strongly with their relative inaction when in office. The Labor government has been able to implement reform without disruption and without having to call in the army or do any of the other types of things that are sometimes called for by people on the other side of the political spectrum.

The honourable member for Lyne referred to the recent Australian Stevedores dispute and tried to suggest that wharfies in some way regard themselves as being special or having greater rights than other workers. I suggest to the opposition that various groups of people in this community regard themselves in that way—none of them is a trade unionist and many of them earn in the vicinity of $150,000 to $200,000 a year. Certainly, waterside workers are not in that category.

I point out for the information of the honourable member for Lyne that the core issue in that dispute with Australian Stevedores was the victimisation of a large number of union delegates—almost half of the 55 people proposed for compulsory redundancy were union delegates. That was the core issue. That is something that has been avoided by the opposition; it is something that is a day-to-day reality for most unions, even in industrially strong areas such as the waterfront. That was the critical issue at stake in that dispute. It is misleading to ignore that issue.

I turn to the general matter of the recent unfair dismissal legislation, which was adverted to by the honourable member for Lyne in his comments. This legislation has been talked up by both employer organisations and the opposition into such a hysterical wave of terror that I believe there are employers out there now who are genuinely worried about taking on more people because they fear the implications of this legislation—not because of anything contained within the legislation but because of the incredible hysteria that has been generated by employer organisations and the opposition. Their hysteria is likely to become a force that prevents employment, in exactly the same way that the opposition says the legislation is in some way inhibiting employment.

The media have had some entertainment talking up some of the initial claims that have been lodged—claims of up to $1 million. Anybody can make a claim saying, `I would like compensation of $500,000, $1 million or $2 million,' but it would be appropriate to reserve judgment on the new system and wait to see what happens with the judging of those claims by the Industrial Relations Commission.

In my short period as a lawyer, I had cause to deal occasionally with county court writs, which certainly at that time in Melbourne, in the jurisdiction of Victoria, always carried a $100,000 claim at the top—even if a person was suing for something that was relatively minor and would never be within a bull's roar of $100,000. Invariably, people who were being sued would get that writ and say, `Oh, my goodness, I am being sued for $100,000.' It was meaningless—a mere form. The same thing applies with respect to some of the more spectacular claims that have been lodged in the unfair dismissal jurisdiction. Time will tell whether we see large payouts and whether we see unfair cost burdens imposed on employers. If experience is any guide in the unfair dismissal jurisdictions both in the states and previously in the federal arena, these results will be very rare indeed.

The core issue that the opposition is missing is that no-one can be dismissed unfairly. The requirements of the legislation are very straightforward. If employers want to dismiss somebody for poor performance, they will need to demonstrate that there has been some form of previous counselling, that their poor performance has previously been drawn to their attention, that an attempt has been made to fix the problem and that they have not just been turfed arbitrarily. If employers want to dismiss somebody for misconduct, they will have to have some evidence. If employers wish to dismiss an employee for stealing, they cannot do that on the basis of a rumour or on the basis of a whim; they will have to have some solid evidence to demonstrate that that employee stole from the company. If employers wish to dismiss somebody in other circumstances and discrimination is involved, they will have a case to answer about whether that person is pregnant, or of a particular race, colour, creed or whatever. These are all legitimate issues on which people are entitled to justice and on which they will now get it on a universal basis.

The important thing about this particular form of legislation is that issues of jurisdiction which have dogged the unfair dismissal system throughout this country for many years will now be avoided. Hours and hours of debate and litigation have occurred in the past, which has meant that, in some instances, cases have gone on for three or four years without people getting justice. That will all be avoided. Questions of interstate jurisdiction and whether people fall within a particular award or not—matters that have caused immense difficulties for people seeking simple justice on their dismissal—will now be avoided. That is something the government deserves great credit for.

Perhaps we can draw some sinister conclusions from the opposition's desire to get rid of that legislation. It will at least get some equity and some fairness into the employment relationship and allow people who have been unfairly dismissed to genuinely pursue their entitlements and to have some hope of getting some sort of justice. If high fliers end up exploiting the system and getting excessive payouts, there will be a case for us to review how the system is operating. But let us wait and see exactly what happens.

The opposition's position is basically that it opposes justice for workers and reforms that are designed to ensure there is some fairness in the employment relationship. Its opposition to this legislation, as I have indicated, has its origins in its basic distaste and dislike for waterside workers, who have been the core, the strength and the vanguard of the Labor movement in its battle for justice in this country. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Mr BRERETON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—In concluding the second reading debate on the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill I thank those government members who have participated in what has been a very stimulating debate on a piece of legislation that we see as being necessary to facilitate a continuation of the waterfront reform process. Government member after government member has taken the opportunity of speaking in the debate. I thank each and every one for their contributions. I think it can rightly be said that they overwhelmed the contributions put forward by the opposition.

PARA.TAB: I want to take a few moments to reply to some of the matters that were brought forward by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp) in their contributions to the debate. What needs to be understood at the outset is that this legislation underpins the waterfront reform process. That is a process which in itself has already seen dramatic improvement both in waterfront productivity and in the general level of enterprise employment on the waterfront. It has been against that background that opposition members have come into this chamber in the course of the debate and have sought quite mischievously to misrepresent the purpose of the bill. I do not think a simple little piece of legislation has been so misrepresented for yonks.

The legislation simply ensures the collection of the special levy which partially finances the redundancy program which has already reduced the labour force on the Australian waterfront by 57 per cent—a 57 per cent reduction which has seen a saving of nearly $250 million per annum in wages and on-costs. One would think that opposition members would have been coming into the parliament to say what a marvellous achievement waterfront reform represents, when we have those sorts of statistics. But no, instead they have sought to misrepresent the purpose of this bill which, as I have indicated to the House, is simply to ensure that the collection of the special levy continues.

This legislation is not aimed at creating labour pools or at seeing a move away from enterprise employment. The opposition has said repeatedly in the debate that it will create labour pools, but that is arrant nonsense; it will not have that effect at all. It is the government's policy, as we have said over and over again, to adhere to ILO conventions. Before government reports to the ILO on its observance of conventions we take the time to seek the views of the ACTU as well as the peak employer organisation, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, on those conventions. I am advised by the department that at no stage whatsoever has the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry raised objections to the ILO 137 in reports to the ILO to date. It has not been at issue. One would think it was the biggest issue in the world from some of the things that have been said by the opposition in this debate. But it has been so much a non-event that it has not been raised by way of objection from ACCI.

ILO 137 does not hinder productivity. That is not its purpose and that is certainly not its effect. The government's approach on ILO 137 is to allow the use of time and wages records or other relevant records, that is, the existing records, the records that are available under the Industrial Relations Act. What this means in practicality is that the adherence to ILO convention 137 using those existing time and wages records and the other relevant records is as simple as possible—unbelievably simple, in fact.

The honourable member for Bennelong did not compare like with like in his contribution to this debate when he compared Australian and New Zealand waterfront costs and reforms. The five to 10 per cent figures he refers to are derived from a Bureau of Transport and Communication economics report for the period 1991 to 1992. Those figures are for total costs, including road transport and brokers' fees. If the honourable member wants to come into the parliament he ought to commit himself to comparing like with like, apples with apples, or, in this charge, real port costs with real port costs.

The New Zealand figures that he has used are for a totally different period. They are understood to be a combination of stevedoring and some port authority charges. This is clearly not a case of like being compared with like. The honourable member for Bennelong should know better than to so misrepresent the purpose and the effect of this legislation, as he has done repeatedly during this debate. Clearly and demonstrably on the facts of the matter the comparison he makes is not valid.

I turn to the contribution of the honourable member for Hume. I told the House not once but indeed on two occasions—let me reiterate it both for his benefit and for the House's benefit—that this bill does not herald the reintroduction of pool employment nor, as he put it to the House, jobs for life. It does not do either of those things. He and the honourable member for Bennelong referred to the TEU loading rates in Sydney and in Melbourne. Their source for this was apparently an Australian Financial Review article of 17 February 1994. The source of that article was one shipping line's internal working paper. What neither gentleman bothered to tell the House, what they both omitted to tell the House, was that the very same Australian Financial Review went on to say that other operators and shipping organisations had taken issue with that report, had disagreed with it. Throughout the period they referred to the average container handling rates remaining at 20 TEUs per hour; average handling rates did not fall.

The honourable member for Hume did not end there; he also claimed that the committee would not close down and would continue, to quote him, `for goodness knows how long'. If only he had read the bill he would see the government's commitment to a sunset provision to ensure that each stevedoring act is repealed when the committee's functions have been fulfilled.

I repeat, in summing up: never has a piece of legislation been so generously misrepresented for reasons of base political motivation and in this bill by both the honourable member for Bennelong and the honourable member for Hume. It is a thoroughly reasonable measure, one necessary to guarantee, as I have said to the House, that this levy continues to be collected. I warmly commend it to the House and to honourable members.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 October last year I supported the private member's motion of my colleague the honourable member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) calling for the government to allocate more money for breast cancer research. Momentum and awareness has built up in the community as breast cancer has received increasing attention in the media. I have often been moved and saddened when listening to individual women speak of their own experience with breast cancer. I felt sheer elation when the subject of breast cancer hit the front page of the Australian, when the Adelaide Advertiser devoted an editorial to the subject, and when the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs heard evidence on the management and treatment of breast cancer. In my electorate all four television channels covered the inquiry. At long last a silent epidemic, which has been tagged `the lady killer', was receiving the attention it deserved.

PARA.TAB: When the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) launched the breast cancer lobby for life campaign, the community joined in. People with varying political loyalties signed petitions seeking more funding for breast cancer research. In excess of 10,000 signatures have come through my office. I place on the record my thanks to the women's groups, bowling clubs, concerned individuals, health professionals, and medical couriers, who assisted me to collect the signatures that I have brought to this House. There have been a few critics—one wishing I would give equal attention to prostate cancer—and there have been arguments that it would be a tragedy if politicians tried to dictate the National Health and Medical Research Council agenda. In reply to these criticisms, there are a number of points I wish to make. I quote the Hansard of last October when I said:

In supporting this motion I am not arguing for sectional interest and I do not suggest that less should be spent on other areas of medical research. We should not reallocate existing resources but rather increase Australia's overall investment in medical research. The fact is that Australia's investment in medical research is too low irrespective of what parameters we examine—1.4 per cent of the total health expenditure when that internationally accepted minimum is 2 per cent. We need to come to see research as an integral component of our health care services. The primary goal of health and medical research must be to achieve better health for all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: It can also be argued that when research into heart disease was increased and a public awareness campaign mounted, the outcomes were favourable: deaths from heart disease are now decreasing while deaths from breast cancer are increasing. There is also the reality that politicians are elected to represent their electorates and to be advocates. I have received enormous encouragement from women and men to highlight this issue. We need to see medical research not only as laboratory research but also as clinical evaluation—that is, evaluation of treatment. If data is not accurately collected and examined, there can be no outcome analysis. While there is an open chequebook through Medicare rebates for diagnosis and treatment of breast cancer, clinical evaluation is hampered, or in some areas non-existent, because of a lack of research dollars.

PARA.TAB: Recently a well-known breast cancer researcher in South Australia received a grant from the United States. This grant was from resources reserved for Third World countries. The grant was to research breast cancer in Aboriginal women, and Australia qualified for it because of the low expenditure on health research as a percentage of GDP. Tomorrow night many Australians will be listening to the budget to hear if there will be a significant increase in funding for medical research. Will the funding be closer to the internationally accepted minimum, or will our researchers still be eligible for grants on Third World criteria?

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the House rose last Thursday evening, I have driven 2,500 kilometres servicing the needs of my electorate. Included in that was a trip to Broken Hill, where I attended its wonderful biannual ag fair. On the Saturday night I also attended the Royal Flying Doctor Service ball, the 500 tickets to which were sold out in eight minutes. It goes to show something of the spirit of the west, even in these difficult times, to support a worthy cause.

PARA.TAB: Probably the highlight of my weekend was receiving a petition from Jenny Camilleri and Anne Slater asking for greater funds for breast cancer research and for other things associated with breast cancer. I handed in petitions from 5,600 petitioners today, 4,500 of which came from Broken Hill, which must surely be the highest amount per capita in Australia presented in this parliament. There are no screening facilities in western New South Wales. There is a New South Wales program overseen by the cancer council, and there have been announcements on the progress of that in recent days. The aim of that program is to reduce deaths in the target group by 30 per cent by the year 2001. About one in 12 women contract a breast abnormality at some stage of their lives. The last figures I had for New South Wales showed that 2,400 new cases of some abnormality turn up every year and that approximately 900 women die every year. So, if this program were fully under way, we could eliminate about 220 deaths per year.

Under the New South Wales program, the state is divided into 16 regions, and the screening and treatment is already up and running in many areas. While one woman across Australia is dying every four hours from breast cancer, nothing has been done as yet in the Orana and far west region and the central west region, which is Bathurst, Dubbo and Orange, west and north. It is intended when these screening units are fully going that they push through between 5,000 and 10,000 women a year. This will be done free instead of women paying $78 each. The target group is specifically the 50-69 year age group, although women as young as 40 and up to 79 years of age will also be screened.

Of course, assessment centres have to be set up and I believe Dubbo has a good chance of having one set up. In these, we will have specialised radiologists, people who can use ultrasound, histopathologists, cytopathologists, specialised surgeons, counsellors and also administrative and data management staff. I welcome the announcement over the weekend that Dubbo, Bathurst and Orange will be receiving screening units. I guess the doctors will probably fly over the area of the west of Bourke, Brewarrina, Cobar, Parkes, Forbes and other towns like this, but I am very concerned that the far western towns will miss out altogether. The Orana and far west region, including even Dubbo, has something less than 35 per cent of the number of women than the average of the other 15 areas in the state. So, taking into account the low numbers, the massive distances involved—the hundreds of kilometres between towns—and also the reality that the target percentage of women screened will be lower because of less awareness of the importance of screening and the high Aboriginal population out there, nothing like 5,000 women will go through these screening units in a year.

If we are to have criteria for these screening units, I believe they have to be relaxed for the western areas. I believe the women of the west have been neglected in this area for far too long. There is a great case to put a screening unit in Broken Hill. It would remain there for a few months of the year and then go out to far-flung towns like Tibooburra, White Cliffs, Wilcannia, Menindee, Ivanhoe and these types of towns where women receive health services only from a royal flying doctor, where there is a high Aboriginal population in some areas and where people who live out there do not even have electricity connected. Surely the very least we can do is provide these women with the same service that exists in larger centres like Sydney. I believe the guidelines should be extended and the women of the west should get a fair crack of the whip for the first time for a long time.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Friday, 28 April, I had the pleasure of attending the official opening of Callide Coalfields new $80 million dragline at Biloela in Central Queensland, which is part of my electorate of Hinkler. The state-of-the-art Indresco 8750 dragline is one of the largest mining machines of its type in the world. In fact, at 130 metres in length, it boasts the longest boom in the world. Moving at a speed of 0.2 kilometres per hour, this walking leviathan can remove 80 cubic metres of overburden with one swoop of its enormous bucket.

PARA.TAB: The dragline's opening, which was part of a total of $100 million expansion by Callide Coalfields Pty Ltd, was a particularly special occasion marking 50 years of operation of the mine. Callide Coalfields has pioneered a remarkable development over the last 100 years. Discovered in 1890 by three prospectors, Callide's rich `black gold' was at that time the thickest coal seam discovered in Australia. Over the next 50 years, Callide attracted the interest of many investors with little result, until in 1943 the Brisbane accountant Lawrence Neill changed the destiny of the fledgling mine.

From 1944, when Theiss Brothers were contracted to remove the overburden and expose the coal, the development of the mine as an open-cut operation mine took off. From a mere 100 tonnes or so production in that year, the mine grew quickly, so that by 1952 Theiss Holdings Ltd owned and operated the whole Callide lease, producing 350,000 tonnes. Callide remained in the Theiss family for almost 30 years, during which time the mine implemented significant advancements in mining technology, including the commissioning of a BE1350 walking dragline in 1976.

In 1980, CSR Ltd took over the Callide mine along with joint venturers Shell and AMP, marking a new expansion era with the discovery and mining of new deposits within the Callide seam, including the opening further north of the Boundary Hill mine in 1982. Today, Callide Coalfields Pty Ltd manages two coalmines, Callide and Boundary Hill, and is a wholly owned subsidiary of Shell Australia on behalf of the joint venturers Shell and AMP. This latest expansion reinforces Shell's position as the major investor in our state and national economies. It is a sign of the organisation's strong confidence in the future of resources development in this country.

Callide Coalfields expansion will consolidate the company's position as an important supplier to the domestic coal market in Queensland. The new electric power dragline at the Callide mine and the refurbishment and relocation of the BE1350 dragline to Boundary Hill, plus improvements as part of this expansion, will see coal production increase from four million tonnes to six million tonnes over the next five years. Through the past 50 years, Callide Coalfields has been a strong and reliable supplier of quality coal for the Queensland economy. The major customers are the Queensland Electricity Commission's Callide B power station at Biloela, Queensland Alumina in Gladstone and the Gladstone Joint Power Venture, which recently acquired the Gladstone power station. The sale of the Gladstone power station is a key element in the expansion of the Boyne smelter to one of the world's largest aluminium smelters.

Since 1944, Callide Coalfields has shown a capacity to anticipate change and implement measures to keep the efficiencies demanded in such a competitive domestic coal market. As well as keeping abreast of technological advancement, Callide Coalfields has sought to improve work practices and training for its highly skilled work force of 400 people. As well as a stringent environmental program, the company has also fulfilled a strong community role, providing much support for the local Biloela economy.

I applaud the Callide Coalfields on its latest expansion and 50 years of progressive and responsible resource management in Central Queensland. I congratulate the mine's manager, Mark West, and his highly focused work force. Callide is a good example of the interaction of industry, technology, work force and community.

Practical annual capacity is the number of annual movements corresponding to an acceptable level of average delay. An annual average delay of 4 minutes is the widely accepted criterion for defining practical annual capacity.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 9 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that $380,000 is paid in unemployment benefits each week in Byron Bay, NSW.
(2) What action is the Government taking to ensure that only those who are genuinely looking for work receive unemployment benefits.
(3) How many persons living in the Byron Bay area have ceased receiving unemployment benefits because they failed to prove they were making a genuine effort to find work.

(4) During his recent interview on the Alan Jones Live television program did he refuse to accept, despite open admissions on camera, that a considerable proportion of persons receiving unemployment benefits in Byron Bay were not looking for work; if so, why.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The figure of $380,000 appears to be based on the total number of Job Search Allowance (JSA) and Newstart Allowance (NSA) clients being paid by the Byron Bay and Brunswick Heads Social Security Offices. In the fortnight ending 28 January 1994, there were 713 JSA and 772 NSA recipients being paid by the Byron Bay Office. These numbers represent a weekly cost in the order of $250,000.

(2) The Government has in place a rigorous set of compliance measures and a comprehensive program of reviews to ensure only those clients genuinely looking for work, or those with an approved exemption, are paid an allowance. The key measures are:

(a) a requirement to lodge fortnightly forms with the Department of Social Security (DSS) indicating work efforts (for JSA clients), interviews at set review points and random reviews chosen by Counter staff; and

(b) selections by Mobile Review Teams using algorithms, where certain variables are run against the data base in each State to identify "at risk" clients, and local initiative-based reviews which rely on local knowledge to identify high risk categories of clients.

The above measures will be enhanced in March 1994 when compliance measures announced in the 1993 Budget are introduced. They include a substantial increase in in-office reviews and fortnightly monitoring by DSS of the efforts to obtain work of Newstart Allowance recipients.
(3) The total number of JSA and NSA recipients cancelled in the Byron Bay area since 1 July 1993 because they failed to prove they were making a genuine effort to find work is 77.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Property Owned by Australian Citizens in Northern Cyprus

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 10 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that at the time of the 1974 Turkish invasion of Cyprus Australian citizens were among those expelled from their ancestral homes in what is now Turkish military occupied territory.

(2) Is it a fact that Australian citizens continue to be denied access by Turkish military occupation forces to their homes and property on the basis that they are of Greek extraction while Anglo-Saxon British citizens have been given free access to any property located in the occupied part of Cyprus which they may have owned before the 1974 invasion.

(3) Is the Australian Government prepared to grant legal aid to those who were (a) Australian citizens before the Turkish invasion, or (b) not Australian citizens before the Turkish invasion but who subsequently became Australian citizens, and who are now dispossessed of their ancestral homes and property, to enable them to pursue their claims in the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg; if not, in either case, will the Australian Government make representations to the Turkish Government to ensure that Australian citizens are treated in the same way as other foreign nationals, particularly the British.

(4) Will the Australian Government make representations to the Turkish Government to ensure that the properties expropriated from Australian citizens are restored to them and not disposed of by the so-called Government of Northern Cyprus.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Government is aware that a number of Australian citizens were expelled from their properties in northern Cyprus after the Turkish invasion in 1974.

(2) In 1975, the Turkish Cypriot administration announced that it would accept property claims from "third party states", that is from individuals not of Greek or Greek Cypriot origin. Most claims lodged by this category of persons, and which could be verified by production of a title deed, have now been settled. Property claims by persons of Greek or Greek Cypriot extraction, or with any Greek or Greek Cypriot links (such as Greek financing of the original purchase), have not been accepted by the Turkish Cypriot administration. While Australian citizens in general are not targeted for special treatment, citizens and residents of Australia who are of Greek or Greek Cypriot extraction are denied access to the north, as are all residents and citizens of other countries of Greek or Greek Cypriot extraction.

(3) The question of the granting of legal aid to Australian citizens, whether citizens at the time of the Turkish invasion or not, is one more appropriately directed to the Attorney-General. A comprehensive negotiated settlement based on the UN Secretary-General's Set of Ideas and which makes provision for the recovery of or compensation for property expropriated, rather than litigation, remains the best hope for those Australian citizens dispossessed in 1974. Australian citizens do not encounter discrimination as compared to British citizens, as outlined in (2) above.

(4) The Australian Government supports a settlement based on the UN Secretary-General's Set of Ideas, including the provisions relating to property, and has encouraged all parties, including the Turkish Government, to continue to work towards such an agreement.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Role of Turkey and Turkish Cypriot Leadership in Seeking Resolution to Cyprus Problems

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 10 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the UN Security Council in 1993 express concern that the Turkish Cypriot side had not yet shown the necessary goodwill and cooperation required to achieve an agreement following the Turkish Cypriot leadership's rejection of (a) Dr Boutros Boutros Ghali, the UN SecretaryGeneral's plan for a solution to the Cyprus problem and (b) more recently, the confidence building measures announced by the Secretary-General for the re-opening under UN control of the now defunct Nicosia International Airport and the uninhabited town of Varosha now under Turkish military occupation.

(2) What representations has the Australian Government made to the Turkish Government to ensure that the Turkish Cypriot leadership adopt the confidence building measures as a prelude to the overall solution of the continued military occupation of Cyprus.
(3) Will the Minister make it clear that Turkey's relations with Australia will suffer if Turkish occupation troops are not withdrawn from Cyprus.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The UN Security-Council, in a letter to the UN Secretary-General dated 20 September 1993, expressed deep disappointment that an agreement to the Cyprus Problem had not been reached, and called on the Turkish Cypriot side to give its support to the effort to secure an agreement on the package. The Turkish Cypriot leadership has now indicated its support for the UN Secretary-General's efforts in general, and specifically the Confidence Building Measures. The Turkish Cypriots and Greek Cypriots have concluded two rounds of proximity talks chaired by the Secretary-General's Special Representative, Mr Joe Clark, designed to develop modalities for implementation of the Confidence Building Measures.

(2) The Australian Government has consistently supported the Secretary-General's efforts to secure a negotiated settlement to the Cyprus problem. We have encouraged all parties to the dispute, including the Turkish Government, to support the Secretary-General's Confidence Building Measures as a means to securing an overall framework agreement.

(3) As part of the Secretary-General's Set of Ideas both Greek and Turkish troop numbers are to be equal and set at a level to be agreed to between the Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot communities. The Turkish Government is aware of the importance the Australian Government attaches to a settlement based on the Set of Ideas.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 22 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What requirements or specifications, other than specification 190(a), has the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) imposed for the installation of emergency location transmitters in light aircraft.
(2) What is the status of handheld models of emergency location transmitters under the requirements or specifications.
(3) Does the CAA require all installations to be finalised by 1 July 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) is in the process of preparing legislation to require the carriage, by all VH-registered aircraft, of automatically activated Emergency Locator Transmitters (ELTs) conforming to either Federal Aviation Administration Technical Service Order (TSO) C91A or TSO C126, with the following exemptions:
balloons;
airships;
sailplanes;
aircraft operating within 25NM of departure point;
aircraft operating within the training area associated with the aerodrome of departure;
aircraft being ferried to a maintenance facility to have an ELT fitted, repaired or overhauled; and
high capacity regular public transport aircraft conducting scheduled operations.

(2) An `impact activation' ELT will be required. `Pocket type' equipment is not suitable. For the `impact activation' benefit to work, it is necessary to have the ELT attached securely to a strong point in the aircraft. The Authority has no intention of mandating this aspect; it will rely on the `manufacturer's mounting instructions'. However, guidance material on fitment will be produced.

It is intended by the Authority that ELTs which are portable, that is, removable from the mounting bracket for use away from the aircraft, or interchangeable between similar installations, will be acceptable.

(3) No. The Authority has received advice that there may be insufficient quantities of TSO C91A ELTs (particularly the lower priced units) presently available in Australia for all owners to comply with the 1 July 1994 deadline. Consequently, the Authority has deferred the introduction date until 1 July 1995.
Notwithstanding, owners and operators will be encouraged by the Authority to fit the equipment to their aircraft as soon as it is available.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 23 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What kind of personal information does his Department require from an applicant for Newstart Allowance (NSA).
(2) How many forms must be completed by a person transferring from NSA to Mature Age Allowance (MAA).
(3) What information do the MAA forms seek.
(4) Is there an overlap between the information on file in respect of NSA and that sought for transfer to MAA; if so, (a) what information is sought a second time and (b) why is it sought.
(5) Will the Government consider amendments to the Social Security Act to enable transfer to MAA on the provision only of information not already held in the Department's database.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) To receive Newstart Allowance (NSA), a person must have provided at some stage a range of information including details of identity, family, employment history, accommodation, income and assets and tax file number.
(2) One. The form is supplemented by a number of different modules which may or may not be required depending on the nature of the client's assets and sources of income.
(3) The MAA claim form is the standard pension claim form. It collects broadly the same information as was originally obtained for the NSA claim.

(4) (a) There is overlap. However, there are differences that relate to the different eligibility rules for MAA (eg. residence qualifications). Much of the information collected on the MAA claim form has been collected as part of a Job Search Allowance (JSA) or NSA claim at some time in the past. This may have been several years previously.

(b) The reason for collecting this information again is that the claim ensures that the client's qualification and entitlement to a particular rate of payment are assessed correctly on the basis of current details. This is standard practice when a client claims a pension type payment for the first time, including where they transfer from JSA or NSA to a pension. MAA recipients who subsequently reach age pension age will be transferred automatically to an age pension without the need for a further claim.
(5) No, it is considered necessary for a full claim for MAA to be made.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 2 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Financial Infrastructure Partnership a partnership between the Department of Social Security, the Governments of Queensland and the Northern Territory, the Australian credit union movement and rural communities.
(2) What is the (a) goal, (b) cost and (c) cost effectiveness of the Financial Infrastructure Partnership.
(3) Who will benefit from the partnership.
(4) Will the focus of the partnership be mainly on predominantly Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities in northern Australia; if so, why.
(5) Will the partnership guarantee the inalienability of cheque payments to clients of the Department; if so, how.
(6) Is there a high incidence of fraud involving cheque payments in the communities referred to in part (4); if so, how will the partnership solve the problem.
(7) What are the existing means for making social security payments.
(8) Will access to the banking system enhance the operation of the welfare system; if so, how.

(9) Is it a fact that (a) 8 regions in rural Australia, where 129 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders live, have been targeted for operation of the Partnership and (b) a minimum of $200,000 in deposits is required to establish a credit union in Australia; if so, how will that volume of deposits be met in those regions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes, but also includes the Departments of Employment, Education and Training, Human Services and Health, Industry, Technology and Regional Development, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and the Trade Practices Commission. The term "partnership" should be read figuratively not literally. There are no legal obligations imposed on any of the parties involved. The Financial Infrastructure Partnership (FIP) seeks the cooperation of the parties only.

(2) (a) The goals of the Partnership are: (i) to facilitate the establishment of credit unions in remote and rural areas lacking banking services so that a range of financial services is available to people living in those areas; and, (ii) to provide improved access to and security of DSS and other payments made to individuals and communities lacking banking facilities.

(b) The Partnership is a coordination mechanism for existing agencies and programs to respond to community proposals to develop credit unions in regions from which banks have withdrawn. Any costs arising from the Partnership are expected to be met from existing funding sources. The only costs to the Commonwealth to date relate to the salary and travel costs of DSS officers consulting with other parties.

(c) Establishing credit unions in locations where DSS currently makes payments by cheque will be cost effective because of the lower costs associated with electronic funds transfer compared with cheque payments.

(3) Individuals and communities which establish a credit union in their area or region will benefit from locally available savings and credit facilities. Clients of the Department of Social Security and other Commonwealth and State agencies will benefit by the greater convenience and security of electronic funds transfer.
(4) Interest from the Credit Union Foundation to date has centred on Aboriginal communities in northern Australia because of the interest in those communities in establishing credit union facilities.
(5) The Department of Social Security is confident that its existing practices meet the inalienability provisions of the Social Security Act.
(7) 97% of Social Security clients are paid by electronic funds transfer to accounts held by clients with banks, building societies and credit unions. The remainder are paid by cheque.
(8) Payment by electronic funds transfer represents a more secure and expeditious payment arrangement for clients.

(9) (a) Eight regions have been identified as the initial focus of the Financial Infrastructure Partnership. These were developed in consultation with the Credit Union Foundation. The figure of 129 represents the number of significant population centres in the 8 regions not the number of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people resident in these areas.
(b) Yes. Raising these funds is the responsibility of local communities.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 3 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the running cost of his Department's Social Policy Division for 1992-93.
(2) What was the average number of departmental officers who worked in the division in 1992-93.
(3) What is the composition and structure of the division in terms of branches and sections.
(4) Will he provide details of all research projects undertaken within the division in 1992-93.

(5) Which research projects undertaken in 1992-93 used data from any of the (a) household expenditure, (b) income distribution and (c) income and housing costs and amenities surveys conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics.
(6) What were the results, findings, conclusions and outcomes of each research project referred to in part (5).

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The running cost of the Social Policy Division of the Department of Social Security for 1992-93 was $5,827,590.00.
(2) The average number of departmental officers who worked in the division in 1992-93 was 114.6.
(3) A chart showing the current composition and structure of the Division in terms of branches and Sections has been forwarded to the honourable member.
(4) In 1992-93, research activity within the Social Policy Division included:
analysis of international data on family allowances;
an estimation of take-up of sole parent pension and family payment;
a file survey of child disability allowance recipients and analysis of the DSS and ABS data;
an analysis of Disability Support Pension and Sickness Allowance using computer matching to assess movements across and out of the income support system;
a review of the effects of key economic and demographic factors on social security policy; and
a review of poverty alleviation and the adequacy of social security income support programs.

The above list is not exhaustive, however because of the nature of the work conducted within the Division it is not cost effective to compile a list of all research projects undertaken during 1992-93.

(5) Because of the wide scope and volume of research projects undertaken within the Division, it is not possible to specify individual projects which utilised the Australian Bureau of Statistics data specified. However, research in areas of housing, poverty, inequalities and families are likely to have utilised this data.

(6) Information in respect of the matters referred to in the honourable member's question is not readily available. To collect and assemble it would be a major task and I am not prepared to authorise the expenditure of money and effort involved in assembling such information.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 3 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister able to say from departmental records how many residents of Australia (a) are of Greek ethnic origin, (b) were born in Greece and (c) speak the Greek Language.

(2) What action has the Minister's Department taken through (a) representations to the British Government, (b) the Commonwealth and (c) UN forums since October 1993 to assist the efforts of the Greek Government to persuade the British Government to return the Parthenon Marbles held in the British Museum to their place of origin.
(3) Has the Minister's Department been assisted in its efforts by the way in which Australia and Britain have the same Head of State.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The most recent Commonwealth profile prepared by the Bureau of Immigration Research within the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, based on the 1986 Australian Census of Population and Housing, states that 336,782 people nominated Greek ancestry as their first or second response regardless of birthplace. 137,611 were born in Greece and 122,884 spoke the Greek language at home. According to the most recent Census of 1991, 136,327 people were born in Greece.

(2) The Australian Government considers that the question of the return to Greece of the Elgin Marbles removed from the Parthenon to the British Museum in the beginning of the nineteenth century, is a matter for resolution by the Greek and British Governments. My Department has not made representations to either the Greek or British Governments, nor in Commonwealth or UN forums on this matter.
(3) The fact that Australia and the United Kingdom have the same Head of State is not relevant to the resolution of this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 22 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: Further to the answer to question No. 816 (Hansard, 1 March 1994, page 1553), how will the Government apply the social security pension assets test to successful claimants for native title.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: In general, a person's native title right or interest would be regarded as akin to a life interest. This is because of the restrictions on the saleability of native title land. All life interests, unless created by the person or their spouse, are exempt under the assets test.
